reviews.text: While there is some history to the European houses here, we felt that its more of a tourist trap as you have to pay entrance fee for each and every house just to view it. We were on our way to the Botanical Gardens anyway, so just passed by this area. Nothing special or anythimg to shout about, but if you really need to see them out of curiosity, then do pay and have a peek. No harm trying. 😁

I went there on golden week of japan. It was a little crowded but if you found hidden paths to go through it was enjoyable. There a some restaurants downhill but I couldn't find a table. I tried a chinese tsukemen.
Not too bad. A bit of a tourist trap and some questionably accurate exhibits, but worth a look if you're passing through and you get quite a good view of Kobe from a high vantage point.

It’s a really nice place to hang out for a day.  There are plenty of museums and preserved old houses to visit. Coffee shops and restaurants choices are abundant, too.
The only thing maybe pushing you back is the slope. Make sure you have a pair of good shoes and prepare to walk.
The streets are soooo beautiful! Very clean, greenery, mural art, minimal cars, and alot of upslope walking.

This is not just a store to buy Mentaiko.
This is an educational facility to learn how mentaiko is produced. Good place for small kids. You’ll love their snacks!! They have ice cream, rice balls, chips etc. bit away from station however it worth go there.
This place is a good attraction. There is a forum to educate about fish eggs and types of fish that are commonly consumed. The mentaiko rice ball tasted great. 😋
There is quite informative and so kids friendly!
Wow! The best free mentai place that I have ever been to. Fun for the whole family! Please come and have a good time. They have mentai ice cream! The world is great!

For mentaiko lovers!

Non mentaiko lovers can still enjoy, just don’t try the ice cream ;D

reviews.text: This was and amazing experience,  natural feel. Its posted on the mountain ⛰ range , its has a sky tram for getting to top. Also nature walk from half way point. All amusement is more kids friendly , natural gardens to walk throw, little bit of hiking as well...I enjoyed it alot 😉. P.S. if windy day...... will be very windy here...
If you love cable cars, he can fulfill all your cable car wishes.  Sea and mountain view, very retro and fun place. In addition, they also have a revolving restaurant overlooking the sea.

An old amusement park located directly beside the Sumaurakoen Station. Although this place looks a little bit old, it has its own charm. You should ride their special escalator to experience the escalator in old times! The old jukebox place was also charming, I played ギンギラギンにさりげなく and had a good time dancing with my friend! The view from the mountain top was beautiful as well, you can see both the mountain and ocean at the same time. Lots of people bring their lunch box and had a picnic there. Overall, I had a good time and would recommend this place for those who like nature and wants to experience 80s/90s nostalgia.
Awesome views, 📸happy Kids,👦⛹️‍♀️ revolving restaurants WOW🥳. 🚗🚠🛩️🛥️
The place was relaxing! I do recommend to  talking a leisurely walk along its paths lines with sakura!

reviews.text:
There are guides, but they don't guide me properly, so when I go to an empty place, I get stopped and have to back up.

data.formatted_address: 1 Chome-3 Higashikawasakicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0044, Japan
data.name: Kobe Harborland

reviews.text: The most beautiful point of Kobe. Quiet , calm and beautiful. There are plenty of attractions nearby this area. A lot of eateries options available. If you have time to spare , I would recommend you go to Concerto Cruise for a sunset or dinner. There is also a seafood buffet restaurant there called Fisherman Village. If you are arriving by train prepare to do a long walk to the harbour front. A lot of Japanese come here during the weekend. This area is attached to Mosaic Mall.

The Kobe harbour is a nice place to spend time. We spent  day in Kobe and after the end of the day it was nice to relax at the harbour. One can walk around,  sit and watch the cruise ship or have lunch/dinner. Kobe Chinatown and Station is within walking distance.

As the sun sets and darkness falls, Kobe Harborland comes alive with a vibrant energy and a magical glow that illuminates the waterfront and creates a captivating spectacle. The twinkling lights of the city skyline reflect off the calm waters of the harbor, casting shimmering reflections that dance and sparkle with every ripple and wave.

At the heart of the night view is the iconic Kobe Port Tower, its elegant silhouette outlined against the darkened sky and adorned with colorful lights that change and shift with the passing moments. From afar, the tower stands as a beacon of welcome and warmth, inviting visitors to experience the beauty and excitement of Kobe's nightlife.

The streets of Kobe Harborland bustle with activity as people gather to enjoy the evening's festivities, with restaurants, cafes, and bars offering delicious cuisine and lively entertainment late into the night. The air is filled with laughter, music, and the aroma of mouthwatering dishes, creating a vibrant and festive atmosphere that adds to the allure of the night view.

As we strolled along the waterfront promenade, we are treated to panoramic vistas of the harbor and the city skyline, with the lights of passing boats and ships twinkling in the distance. The illuminated skyscrapers and landmarks of Kobe create a stunning backdrop for the scene, while the tranquil waters of the harbor reflect the colorful lights like a mirror, enhancing the sense of magic and wonder.

Throughout the evening, the night view at Kobe Harborland evolves and changes, with the shifting patterns of light and shadow creating an ever-changing kaleidoscope of colors and shapes. From the soft glow of street lamps to the neon brilliance of illuminated signs, every corner of the waterfront district is bathed in a warm and inviting light that beckons visitors to explore and discover its hidden treasures.

A beautiful harbour, well designed and maintained, which was nice to visit on a sunny 😎 and windy🍃 winter morning.

Ferris wheel 🎡, port tower🗼 and harbour ferries ⛴️ are all iconic elements that represent Kobe as a port city. The museum, art exhibits and various shopping malls like Mosaic, North mall and South mall right here will ensure that you'll put aside at least half a day to properly browse the place.

Ample parking is available in the vicinity.

The beef hotpot here is very delicious, the spring rolls are soft and delicious. Buffer should eat and drink comfortably. Beef dipped in sauce with super delicious mushrooms and vegetables. There are many types of beer and wine drinks to choose from. Especially, there is super delicious fresh ice cream for dessert

data.formatted_address: Midoridai, Suma Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 654-0163, Japan

reviews.text: Hilly, its my first time to get there by bicycle,l. I want to go inside arena but i have to go just took some pics hope you enjoy it.

Great for camping, walking, doing sports and activities, but no stores only a lawson and a tiny family mart around the station. If you bring your food you can enjoy it there. The natural setting is awsome. Don't miss the cosmos hill.
Very convenient to reach.

Easy access to the stadium by train and the  parking space. You will get stuck in traffic on your way out so don't park on the roof of the parking. The stadium is starting to show it's age both in and out. The food is a bit on the scary side so bring your own snacks.
Beautiful Park with several kinds of flowerz and space to walk, camp and picnic.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-4-3 Kitanochō, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0002, Japan
data.name: Kobe Nunobiki Herb Gardens & Ropeway

reviews.text: The gondola ride was absolutely spectacular, breathtakingly beautiful, and the views were simply stunning. This is a must-do when in Kobe. As you can see from my photos, the scenery is incredible. The top is very beautiful, with the garden being amazing—absolutely wonderful. You can walk down, and they put a lot of effort into the botanical gardens and vegetable gardens they've created. Truly an amazing day trip, even half a day is enough. A definite recommendation.

You can easily spend at least a couple of hours here if you want to see all the little herb gardens and look around the shop and cafe along the way up or down. There’s also a cable car which you need to take at least one way unless you want to hike for most of the day.
There is an incredible variety of herbs and plants which are very well looked after. There are signs with the English names of the plants and a QR code you can scan for more information.
You can see a waterfall and have a great view of Kobe on the cable car or even walking up or down the gardens.
It’s not open at night all year round so you’ll need to check the times for that if you plan to go at night.

A delightful moment at this incredible garden. Easy to find from shin Kobe station, just follow the indications (you have to go threw a little mall). It was a Monday so we didn’t buy our tickets in advance. It was not crowded. We loved the ropeway. In June there was a lot of hydrangeas. The museum of fragrance was interesting. The footpath was a refreshing.

I should have save more time for this garden. I believe you can walk all the way up from the Kobe station but that is quite a hike if you are already walking around the city and the gardens after entry. Save yourself and take the cable car up. Enjoy the scenery. Lavender ice cream is at the stand beside the cable car entry for going down the hill. The cafe at the greenhouses has a specialty flavor of the season and the ice cream at the top is vanilla. Lots to smell, see and plenty of places to sit. Including hammocks. Make your own adventure here.

A must see in Kobe! Great herb garden. Products there are extremely natural, affordable as well as high-quality. Ropeway is scenic. Free foot jacuzzi for a break before the hike down. Lavender icecream there tasted amazing.

December 4 , 2021 ( 16:00 )

Not so crowded but worth visiting. Beautiful very big park to do some activities and enjoy with family and friends . Parking is free for 1 hour after that it will be charge . Wheelchair ♿️ ok 👌. Toilets 🚽 are available in every corner of the park . Beautiful place with lots of trees. I thing Sakura time April will be the best time to visit this place .

Loved the camping, but... that is not a family friendly pool and that one lady on lifeguard duty is just way too strict for it to be any fun. She definitely ruined our last day. I apparently wasn't allowed to wear a swimmer pro rubber necklace because it could fall off but they had to look for someone's goggles... Kids got in trouble for using two float boards, I got in trouble for holding their float board despite a lot of other dad's doing it for their kids (I'm the big foreigner so I guess I'm easier to find?) Decent place but the pool is wayyy to strict and you can barely have any fun.
I got yelled at by the life hard for doing a handstand where there were no people. The pool gets a 2/10 star review, the rest is ok
Nice place, full of green and spacious places.

The perfect family getaway. Activities for the family, bring your children and friends. Have a picnic or eat at the cafeteria. We had curry and rice. Plenty of parking space, and camping as well. Conveniently located off the highway.

data.formatted_address: 5-5 Hatobachō, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan
data.name: Kobe Port Tower

reviews.text: I have been up many observation decks around the world, and this one certainly didn’t disappoint. There is an internal viewing gallery, as well as an area on the roof you can walk around. The views are fantastic. There is a revolving restaurant where you can order a basic meal, as well as a gift shop. There is ample parking nearby (for a fee). Admission is inexpensive. Definitely worth checking out if you’re in Kobe.

This was such a neat thing to see after it finally reopened following being closed due to Covid and then immediately after for renovations. The view was great and was a fun time to take in the area. The art floor and cafe area was nice. The drink was a nice treat to try while I think the food they offered in the rotating cafe was a bit expensive. I recommend buying tickets in advance via the website as they do have a cap on the number of people that may enter at any one time. While you can buy tickets at the tower for a time slot that has available tickets, the fact you can buy them on the website makes certain times go very quickly on certain days. It cost 1200 yen to go to the very top or 1000 yen to go to the observation area. Very nice time.

Fairly cheap for an amazing view. Not that crowded around sunset midweek surprisingly. Reserving tickets in advance made things simpler. The interactive light show on the way down reminded me of team epsom experiences in Tokyo.

At 108 meters (354 feet) tall, the Kobe Port Tower offers visitors the opportunity to ascend to its observation deck and enjoy breathtaking views of Kobe and its surroundings.

In addition to its breathtaking views, the Kobe Port Tower also offers a range of amenities and attractions for visitors to enjoy. The tower's lower levels house exhibition spaces, souvenir shops, and restaurants, where visitors can learn about Kobe's history, culture, and maritime heritage while savoring local cuisine and picking up unique souvenirs.

Throughout the year, the tower is illuminated in a dazzling array of colors and patterns, creating a spectacle that lights up the night sky and adds a touch of magic to the waterfront area. Whether viewed from afar or up close, the tower's vibrant lighting serves as a beacon of welcome and warmth for visitors to Kobe.

Nice view from Kobe port tower. It was raining but we picked the sunset slot to try to get some daytime and nighttime views
Definitely buy tickets in advance
We got the tix with the meal option, the burger wasn’t bad but nothing too special
At night the views are pretty good. Also the restaurant is rotating so you get views of different angles while you eat

data.formatted_address: Nunobikiyama Fukiaicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0058, Japan
data.name: Nunobiki Falls - Mentaki

reviews.text: This was a hidden gem and an easy hike. A lot of locals and very few foreigners. Look out for this blue light display, you might see cars parked along the road. There will be signs at the station, or arrows, pointing to the start of nunobiki hike. Walkup the road and follow the trail up to the two waterfalls. Walk further to get to the reservoir.
Short hike in the wilderness in the middle of Kobe. On a hot day the hike makes it a relief from the scorching heat of the sun. Definitely worth the quick 15 to 20 min asend up a local hill.
Short hike up about 300m to waterfall, although there are some steep stairs along the way. Easily accessible from Shin-Kobe station.

I recently had the pleasure of visiting the enchanting 布引 waterfall, and I must say it left a lasting impression on me. With its remarkable beauty and tranquil surroundings, this waterfall provided a perfect resting spot before my mountain climbing adventure. I would rate it 4 out of 5 stars.

First and foremost, the waterfall itself is undeniably beautiful. As the water cascades down the rocky cliffs, it creates a mesmerizing display of nature’s power and elegance. The sight of the crystal-clear water falling gracefully into the pool below is truly a sight to behold. I found myself captivated by the rhythmic sound of the flowing water, which added to the overall serenity of the place.

Moreover, the location of the waterfall is strategically positioned as a convenient resting point before embarking on a mountain climbing expedition. The surrounding area provides ample space to relax and rejuvenate, allowing visitors to recharge their energy for the upcoming hike. Sitting by the waterfall, I felt a sense of tranquility washing over me, providing the perfect opportunity to pause, reflect, and prepare for the adventure ahead.

One of the highlights of my visit was the ability to enjoy the waterfall while taking a break. There are designated areas near the waterfall where visitors can sit, rest, and soak in the breathtaking view. It was a wonderful experience to find a comfortable spot, breathe in the fresh air, and bask in the mesmerizing beauty of the cascading water. This combination of relaxation and natural beauty created a serene atmosphere that made the visit truly memorable.

While I thoroughly enjoyed my time at 布引 waterfall, there is one aspect that could be improved. The accessibility to the waterfall could be enhanced with clearer signage or directions, as it took a bit of effort to find the exact location. However, once I arrived, the experience more than made up for the initial challenge.

In conclusion, 布引 waterfall is a truly remarkable destination, offering a tranquil and picturesque respite for nature enthusiasts and adventurers alike. Its stunning beauty, combined with its convenient location as a resting point before climbing the nearby mountain, makes it a worthwhile visit. Despite minor navigation difficulties, I rate this waterfall 4 out of 5 stars for its serene ambiance and remarkable natural splendor.

One of the chain of Nunobiki waterfalls. This mentaki one is the easiest waterfall to be visited as it is very near from the Shin-Kobe station. The view was amazing. And you can just simply walks here after several altitude.  Very comfortable as you can sit in front of the waterfall to enjoy its beauty. I visit this place during summer, but I think the scenery will be better during autumn. The location was very near from the main road also.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒651-1102 Hyogo, Kobe, Kita Ward, Yamadachō Kamitanigami, 字長尾1-2
data.name: Kobe Municipal Arboretum

reviews.text: Absolutely lovely botanical park and garden with long, winding paths through a diverse array of trees and greenery. Each visit reveals new seasonal wonders, from vibrant spring blooms (azaleas and cherry blossoms are breathtaking!) to fiery autumn foliage. A serene escape within Kobe, ideal for leisurely strolls, picnics, and nature photography. Extensive grounds offer various trails and hidden nooks for exploration. Don't miss the charming ponds, bridges, and occasional wildlife sightings. The arboretum is well-maintained with helpful signage and amenities (restrooms, vending machines). A must-visit for nature enthusiasts and those seeking tranquility amidst the city buzz.

Indispensable place to enjoy Natural atmosphere is here deep into the Rokko Mountain Range, situating 10 km to the East from Kita-Suzuran-Dai St. As a matter for regret, not so convenient place for pedestriant as it is, some effort might be required to visit the Natural place.
You may kill at least half a day here, as a hiker, as a family and as a photographer including a bird watcher.
Restaulant supplies meals, drink machinery is prepared. Wheelchair users available.
Anyway, a best care might be taken while winding road driving not to cut in center line for safety.

I visited on 22/11/2023. There is the free shuttle bus at Kitasuzurandai station. The bus was punctual, and it wasn't crowded. The natural surroundings and scenery were beautiful, offering a relaxing experience as I walked around and enjoyed the views.
It’s a great place to go to feel nature in Kobe, very pleasing colours on the eye and plenty of fresh air.

Big park with nice scenery and views.

Definitely coming here again :)

Parking is kinda overpriced, its 500 yen!

When it got dark, the reflection of the cherry blossoms on the water was beautiful.
It's beautifully lit up and worth a look.
But this year's illumination will only last until today...

I took my dog ​​for a walk from parking lot P5. It seems that dogs were not allowed in until 04/07.
It's hard to enjoy it when there are too many people, but on weekends you can take a leisurely stroll during the morning and evening hours.

Autumn leaves light up🍁 It was so beautiful. Although it was the last day of the illumination period, we were able to enjoy it leisurely without getting crowded. Next time I would like to see the Japanese garden during the day.

reviews.text: I look forward to seeing the cherry blossoms in the Ikuta River every year. It was cloudy again this year, but the cherry blossoms were in full bloom and it was beautiful. Sakura-san ❤️ Thank you 🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸🌸
Ikuta River flows in front of Shin-Kobe Station. The cherry blossoms were so beautiful. Many cherry blossoms bloom early this year, but they are still blooming beautifully here.

Close to Shin-Kobe Station, it is a place where you can take a walk while looking at the cherry blossoms and enjoy cherry blossom viewing under the cherry blossoms.
There are stairs going down and you can also sit by the river.
In 2023, it was in full bloom on March 25th.
The cherry blossoms were the best (-ω☆) Kirari

I've been there before and know that the cherry blossoms are beautiful, so this time I went out of my way to arrive 30 minutes before boarding the Shinkansen and wanted to see the cherry blossoms here one more time. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to take many pictures as I was dragging my suitcase, but I hope you can see how beautiful it is.

data.formatted_address: 5-chōme-3-1 Nakayamatedōri, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0004, Japan
data.name: Sorakuen Garden

reviews.text: Splendid Japanese garden with several water falls, a lake with koi carps, and historical buildings. A perfect place for photography, or just to relax.

A beautiful traditional japanese garden. The personel at the entrance are very friendly and the garden eventhough it is not huge is very beautiful. The area with the pond and the koi is absolutely beautiful!

A beautiful small zen and typical Japanese 🇯🇵 garden.
The entry costs JPY 300 as of Feb. 2024.

Although only a part of the garden is under reconstruction, the traditional garden, "Sorakuen" with wedding halls is well worth visiting and enjoying at any rate.
There is no shortage of locations for pre-wedding photos by professional workers.
Of particular note is the pleasure boat built during the Edo period for the exclusive use of the Himeji castle lord, called "Funayakata" !
The only surviving gold-plated boat, one of the important national cultural property, has been relocated to the shore of a pond and is now permanently displayed. It may be worth visiting more than Kyoto's Kinkaku-ji Temple, where you can see things like this only here.
To get to Sorakuen from the nearest subway station, you have to climb a slope, and there are ups and downs from the gate to the garden, which must be difficult for wheelchair users. There are toilet rest area and a drink vending machine.
Free of charge for Hyogo prefecture residents, 300 yen for outsiders.

It is autumn and many leaves have already turned red. There are a lot of locals going in and out, and many are doing photoshoot wearing yukata as the scenery was breathtaking. It was healing and calming.

reviews.text: The best night view place in Mt. Rokko

Great view overlooking Hanshinma

10 minutes walk from Cable Yamagami Station
The stairs are a little difficult. Those who go should wear comfortable shoes!

A hidden night view spot. The road to get there is a little rough, but there are no lights around and the stars are beautiful. I visited in winter and the pictures showed the Pleiades star cluster and the constellation of Orion.
If you go with your loved one, this is a place where you can say, “The moon is beautiful.”

I didn't have enough time to park my car a little further away and take a walk, so I parked in front of a sign on the side of the path and walked for 2.3 minutes.
I was able to see a wonderful and liberating view!

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-20-4 Kitanochō, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0002, Japan
data.name: Uroko House

reviews.text:
I found the exterior and the architecture quite pleasing. It was nice to sit in the courtyard and admire it for a while.

There are some nice paintings and items inside (find the fish scale chinaware!) but these on their own wouldn't form enough of a reason for me to go there.

Staff is polite and the house is objectively interesting both for domestic tourists and foreigners curious to see a European style XIX century house in the middle of Japan. But the price is quite notable compared to how much you actually get to see, and the souvenir shop doesn't accept credit cards below ¥1000. Also there's only one toilet (the whole area has very few public toilets due to its eccentricity and high altitude) and it's incredibly small and dense (but I still appreciate that it was there in the first place).

You might want to ask yourself how badly you want to visit this place, especially if it entails a detour of some sort
A glimpse of Western style architecture 💛 enjoyed thinking how the life it would be during those days! 😊

One of the best place to visit in Kitano-Ijinkan, I think. Here, you can also take picture with the wild boar statue which they believes could bring you the best luck. Also, here you can observe the scenery of Kobe city from the third floor. If you want, you can observe other buildings as it is a cafe, I think. I enter this place for free using the happy memory pass.
It's more expensive than other places (1050 yen), but it's got a lot to see and great quality. Nice house and art gallery, plus the sundaes in the shop were delicious. Get the matcha one for sure!

data.formatted_address: 6 Chome-4 Kanocho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0001, Japan
data.name: East Park (Higashi Yūenchi)

reviews.text: It's a very nice corner in a busy city. Not just open space, but also a coffee shop and a book stand in the park. It's only a couple of blocks away from the super-busy Sannomiya area, but with a completely different vibe. It's quiet and calm here, even at the rush hours when office workers and students passing through, it still offers a good atmosphere of relaxation.
The grass was so clean, and there were people doing picnics and playing on the grass. Definitely worth visiting!!

A good spot to chill and hang out. Gets especially busy during the Kobe Luminaire in December.
A short walk from Merekin Park and Motomachi JR Station. Takes about 30 mins from Shin Kobe Station.

Gathering spot for two major events that memorialize victims of the Great Hanshin Awaji earthquake of 1995: Luminarie and an annual memorial service on January 17, the day of the earthquake. Open year-round and accessible from all directions including an underground passage. Located ocean-side of the Kobe City Hall and a 15 minute walk from JR, Hankyu, and Hanshin Sannomiya stations. An earthquake memorial is located at the far end.
A great park with water playground for kids, a cafe, toilets and seats to relax.

reviews.text: I took my family here after growing up as a child with Anpanman. It brought back a lot of nostalgia and was an amazing time for my children. It was super crowded though so prepare for that, BUT the staff and overall experience were top notch!

This area is better aimed at toddlers than children. In our opinion, the entrance fee (2,200¥) is quite expensive for the playground and facilities available. My 5 year old child enjoyed the facilities outside the paid area more.

The place is awesome and suitable for young kids who love Anpaman. Entry ticket cost 2000 yen but they do have some discounts for kids and the ones who are vaccinated.

My kids who are 12 and 14, didn’t want to enter as they found the place boring, however, we managed to have some anpaman breads with characters and different flavors. Kids enjoyed it.

The place has some other entertainment varieties and connected to Mosaic mall with lots of eateries and stores around.

Ferry wheels is good but it’s only a short ride. Wish if it were longer.

Located next to the harbour, you can enjoy the sea and ships views with beautiful mountains backdrops.

For 2,000 yen per person over 1, I was really expecting a better experience. For the most part this is basically a glorified indoor playground. It does have a few cool things like a meet and greet with Anpanman and a quick 10 minute show, but overall quite disappointing.
I did not enter the museum but the statues and decorations of Anpanman outside the museum makes me feel this is a nice place for kids to visit. Also, they make Anpanman breads which looks very cute.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-5-5 Higashikawasakichō, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0044, Japan
data.name: Kobe Brick Warehouse

reviews.text: Interesting spot to rest.. lots of furry friends visiting
Splendid
Excellent night view
Coffee festival Kobe

I've been visiting Kobe for almost 30 years, but I didn't know there was a Red Brick Warehouse in Harborland.

I wandered around the place and saw it in a very fashionable and atmospheric place.

There were some restaurants that seemed to have delicious food, but unfortunately I ate at umie, so I'll probably stop by another time.

There was also Nagasawa stationery, and the kids were happy to buy glass pens.

The place is not very conspicuous, but many people come here regularly, so it seems like everyone knows it.

data.formatted_address: 24 Kyōmachi, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0034, Japan
data.name: Kobe City Museum

reviews.text: A good place to know about Kobe's history! You could go through the permanent exhibition without fee, only pay for the special one !

Came today and saw the Ghibli exibition. Great exibition which focused on the designing, planning and building of the Ghibli museum in Tokyo and theme park in Nagoya. I wad particular intrigued by the design and construction process of Howl's moving castle in real scale, seeing the details the team go into to make a structure in the animation into a real building was so inspiring.

Very useful to gain an insight of how Kobe began as a port and melting pot of foreigners and locals as well as its importance as a major port city. Definitely useful to visit the museum first to have a better appreciation of Chinatown and buildings in the foreign settlement area where this museum is located. The first floor is a must visit showcasing the history of Kobe with nice videos and exhibits of the old and new Kobe streets and buildings and it's free too! The second and third floors are special exhibits. It's a relatively small museum and easy to visit in an hour. Photos below for your preview and do come here first before exploring the rest of the city. 👍

We visited the Egyptian mummy exhibit. The museum was beautiful and clean with helpful staff and plenty of audio options for tours. The mummies are from a more recent age including Roman occupation, so they are not as ancient. However, they are in excellent condition, and the CAT scans reveal a lot. Lots of artifacts and interesting stonework is included. Very cool if you like ancient Egypt. The downstairs Kobe history area is also interesting.
The museum could have been interesting had it taken the effort to include a few explanations in English - the universal language known to all !

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒658-0032 Hyogo, Kobe, Higashinada Ward, Kōyōchōnaka, 2-chōme−９−１ 神戸ファッションプラザ 1F
data.name: Kobe Fashion Museum

reviews.text: Well, it's not a fashion museum anymore. We took the train to visit in February of 2024 and all of the fashion related exhibits are closed. They have exhibits of large paintings of women looking bored, trees, sculptures of naked people standing around, and some pretty vases and abstract elements. It was an enjoyable art exhibit, but false advertising for sure. The Fashion Museum branding is still all over the tickets and building, which is why I came away with a bit of a bad taste in my mouth after paying $20 for a ticket to a completely different exhibit than what is advertised.
just okay - they had a fine arts exhibition on which was quite nice, but nothing worth returning to

Saw the Takarazuka Revue costume exhibit on the last day. It was displayed nicely, with lots of elements including multiple videos and a model of a stage layout. Entry price was reasonable, service was fast, staff were diligent to protect the collection by politely making sure I was using a pencil to take sketches rather than ink which sounds damage something. I'd like to see other exhibits, but it seemed like there was only the one exhibit at that time. I could have missed things, though. Will come back.

This place is not worthy to pay for a visit unless you want to see the island and just passing by (or you're lucky enough to be there during an interesting exhibit). Nothing to see except the building itself.
By the way, they don't have those amazing toilets... such a disappointment since you kinda get used to the ones, lol.
I really like this museum. So interesting.

data.formatted_address: 4-chōme-5-5 Sumiyoshi Minamimachi, Higashinada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 658-0041, Japan
data.name: Hakutsuru Sake Brewery Museum

reviews.text:
This is a museum about one of the top sake brand in Japan. I came to this museum after the 菊正宗酒造記念館. They both have exhibitions introducing the sake production process. The stuff they displayed and the details they mentioned are different, thus, it gives you even better understanding after visiting more than one museum.

The 白鶴酒造資料館 provided life-sized wax people to help visitors understand the literal explanation of sake production even better.

The souvenir shop sells many different sake, as well as some interesting products, such as curry and carbonara sauce made with rice sediments of sake production. They also offer sake flavor ice cream!

After learning about deeper cultural and spiritual background of sake production, I felt more admiration and respect towards all the people who  devoted themselves to the quality of sake and preservation of this legendary sake brand which weathers through history.

When in Kobe, you definitely have to go to a Brewery! This brewery museum is FOC, you get to walk the exhibition at your pace, and its not crowded. At the end of the museum, there is a gift shop and sake tasting available.

We paid 500Yen to get a sake glass & 2 tokens, which you then go to the sake dispensing machine to pick your choice of sake. The sake glass is also a souvenir to take home! There are also other fruit flavoured sakes available for tasting. We loved the whole experience given that it was totally very free and easy, not a tourist filled place!

It is a walk from the nearest train station but no complains as the walk here was very relaxing, the neighbourhood is quiet.

Will recommend!

Fabulous Museum and shop. I just hung out, inside n out, tasted sake and had a sake soft serve ice-cream in the garden. My favourite. Then of course bought sake. Visited again, from my stay on Rokko Is. buying more sake for myself and my host guest, Glenda, who is a doll. 🎎 🎋💮💕

Enjoyed my visit to this sake brewery museum.
No booking required, free entrance. There is a little bit translation to English, if you don’t speak Japanese.
At the end you can buy different kinds of sake, as well as do some tasting - free and paid. Don’t skip getting sake ice cream - it’s delicious!

Went to sake brewery as I was getting bored of Osaka and wanted to head to Kobe area. Found it by chance based on the stop I will get off at and saw that they have free sake sampling. Went there and walked through the entire exhibit to understand more about sake making. Very interesting and they have QR code where you can scan to listen to the English explanation. There were 3 different types of sakes for free samples and other types where you had to pay. The souvenir shop was filled with plenty of Japanese sake. I definitely regret not getting their sake skincare products as a souvenir because my luggage was already too heavy for me. Instead, I had ice cream.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-5-2 Wakinohamakaigandōri, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0073, Japan
data.name: The Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake Memorial Disaster Reduction and Human Renovation Institution

reviews.text: This exhibit immortalises the 1995 earthquake which almost leveled the city. There are artefacts, eyewitness testimony, as well as interactive exhibits targeting children. There were multiple theatres showing films about emergency preparedness. They provide translators which you can wear, but it can be difficult to hear over the Japanese dialogue being played at full volume throughout the room. If you’ve been to the museums in Hiroshima or Nagasaki, you will have a good idea of what to expect. There is an immersive experience at the beginning of the tour which I didn’t enjoy; as it had a lot of flashing lights, loud noises, and blurred imagery (but everyone is different). There are two buildings, with the second containing exhibits which largely target Japanese children. Worth having a look if you’re interested in contemporary history, or don’t know much about the science behind earthquakes. Admission is inexpensive. Paid parking available nearby.

If you're traveling to Japan, I would recommend going to Kobe to see this memorial museum. The Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake Memorial museum was stark and humbling experience of what impact earthquakes can have on us. They had a plethora of video recordings, recollections and interviews of survivors, simulation areas, suggestions on how to better prepare for natural disasters, and more. We stayed for almost three hours and would have spent longer if not for an engagement we had to make thereafter. Highly, highly recommend this.

Great place to learn about history of the Kobe earthquake and how to prepare for natural disasters. Good place to go to educate yourself on why they happen and what to do when one happens. Do not worry if you do not know japanese , they provide headsets for translation.

It was more interesting and entertaining than most memorials. They have a short movie 🎥 to watch, Interactive activities and simulation.

PS - They also have a cafeteria on the first floor. The menu is shown in the last picture.

Good education for the younger children and as well as adults. To create more awareness to public, although my country Singapore, does not have any nature disaster, we also can play our role by not harm the world by doing 3Rs. Everyone do our part. Highly recommended.

data.formatted_address: 7-chōme-7-6 Minatojima Nakamachi, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0046, Japan
data.name: Bando Kobe Science Museum

reviews.text: Nice place to bring your kids. Family friendly. ¥600 for exhibition and ¥400 for planetarium (price may differ).

Regret but not suitable for foreigners since all the information is in japanese. The only good thing is planetarium but the entrance fee will be double if you want to watch planetarium. The building and inside is a bit old.
This is a fun place to be, both adult and child. I love the future reporter area. Planetarium is good but quite warm.
nice place for kids also there is a cozy cafeteria on 1st floor. Having simple meal after playing is comfortable. We stay for 3hrs.
Nice place for both children and adults to understand why science is important for Daily life.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-3-29番1号 Ōishi Minamimachi, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0852, Japan
data.name: Sawanotsuru Museum

reviews.text: This was informative and very interesting history of sake. The tasting and shop was great as well!

Back to Kobe for the second part of my sake breweries tour. This is Day 2 of exploration which I went solo. Day 1 was the first 3 breweries that I visited last year to buy some goodies I want to bring back. This one was one of the furthest of the few breweries in the area so quite difficult to visit all 6-7 of them at once since they close early in the evening too. Anyways, nice small shop. Recommendations of the day were umeshu and nama genshu. Some Valentine's chocolates too.

We enjoyed visiting this place. The history was fantastic.
The video in the main hall is played in multiple languages so we got to enjoy the video which explained the sake making process.

At the end of the tour, there were 2 sakes we could try which we nice, but other places on our sake tour had 3 or 4 sakes to try.

Would recommend visiting this place just to see the history behind sake.

Interesting sake museum with real old school sake making tools on display. There is a 10 minutes introduction video in Japanese and English. There are 2 kinds of wine to take at the end of the tour. Lots of yummy otsumami to taste at the gift shop. Very friendly usher personnel. Not very crowded on a Friday afternoon.

Sake Museum with store and sake tasting.
Admission fee free (as of Oct 2nd 2021).
You can make a self tour in the museum there are placards in English and Japanese.
In the store you will find different types of Sakes with attractive prices.

data.formatted_address: 797 Arimachō, Kita Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-1401, Japan
data.name: Arima Toys and Automata Museum

reviews.text:
Fun little Museum.

I took my gf there cause she loves nutcracker. But it turned out to be unexpetedly fun for both of us.

This is a place where children can enjoy and experience simple retro wooden toys, and adults can be taken back to their childhood.

Even if you do not enjoy playing the toys, you can still marvel on the design, crafmanship, and thoughtfulness of the toy maker.

We only had an hour at the museum, but we wish we had a bit more time to play. So i would suggest sparing around 1.30 - 2.00 hours to fully enjoy this place. For us, it was well worth 800 JPY tickets.
Well worth the visit and the 800 yen entry! We stumbled across the Arima Toys and Automata Museum and enjoyed the experience!

We came just because we had extra time but we were happy to come here by accident - it was a small but beautiful museum. There were 6 different floors with different themes - mostly European toys. They also had stalls and tables for you to try some of the toys displayed. A totally unexpected experience but it was worth it.

The Arima Toys and Automata Museum, nestled in the charming town of Arima Onsen, offers a delightful escape into a world of wooden toys and automata. As a fan of traditional toys, I couldn't resist exploring this hidden gem during my recent visit to Japan.

Upon entering the museum, I was immediately captivated by the nostalgic ambiance that permeates every corner. The collection of wooden toys on display is extensive and impressive, showcasing the craftsmanship and artistry of past centuries. From handmade dolls to intricate puzzles, each piece tells a unique story and represents a slice of history.

The museum has done an excellent job of curating exhibits that showcase the evolution of toys over time. I particularly enjoyed the sections dedicated to traditional Japanese toys, which shed light on the cultural significance and symbolism behind these charming creations. It was fascinating to see how these toys have evolved and remained beloved through generations.

One highlight of my visit was witnessing the mesmerizing automata displays. These whimsical mechanical toys come to life with intricate movements, adding a touch of magic to the museum experience. Watching the dancing figurines, graceful music boxes, and cleverly designed automata was truly enchanting and brought out the childlike wonder in me.

I was pleasantly suprised that there were play areas in the building and that you can interact with the installations. I almost didn't go here because I thought that they will have macabre gothic displays. On the contrary, they have cute displays, and Christmas themes. My favorite display has to be the Arima pens with the peekaboo dolls and the talls piano stairs.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒658-0032 Hyogo, Kobe, Higashinada Ward, Kōyōchōnaka, 5-chōme−７ 六甲アイランド公園内
data.name: Koiso Memorial Museum of Art

reviews.text: The art on exhibit is suited to our taste and very well presented! A place worthy of a trip! The apartments in west court 3 is very nice 👍!!
Simple, peace, comfortable museum..

Right after getting off at Rokko Island Kitaguchi Station. It was empty even though it was a Sunday, probably because I had to transfer from Sannomiya (there was a bus from a nearby hotel to Sannomiya, so be prepared with ¥400 in change) and I was happy to have a leisurely look around. It's horizontal and there are more exhibits than I expected, so it will probably take you more than 2 hours to look at it carefully. There are many chairs in the building (I don't know because I don't use the restroom), but there are no stairs, making it barrier-free and wheelchair-friendly. However, the explanatory text is at the bottom, so if you are standing you will have to bend over to read it. Also, small fonts are difficult to read. I think it is a building that is quiet and calm and can be viewed as a whole. Ryohei Koiso's relocated atelier also looks nice.

I've visited twice in the past year.
The first time was when there was an exhibition focusing on the connection with Iku Takenaka, but this time I stopped by as if I was there when there was an exhibition on Hide Kawanishi at the Kobe-related museum, which is also located on Rokko Island. . But this time, I preferred the exhibit at the Koiso Memorial Museum of Art, and I was moved by how amazing their friendship was. The egg sandwich was fluffy and delicious with pickles🫑
The second time was for the Higashinada Karuta Stamp Rally, the Real Mystery Game Museum, and the Mysterious Door. It was an exhibit by a manga artist I don't know (sorry), but it was fun and had content that made me want to read it. The stacked stamps were located just before the exit after all the exhibits were finished, and the mystery-solving game was inspired by the permanent part of Mr. Koiso's atelier.
If you show the Hyogo e-Prefecture app, you can get a discount on the admission fee 😌

This is an art museum that permanently displays paintings by Ryohei Koiso, but you need to be careful.
About once a year, there is a special exhibition different from Mr. Koiso's, and during this period you can only see about 40 of Mr. Koiso's paintings.
I was caught off guard because it was labeled as the "Koiso Memorial Museum of Art." I was really looking forward to seeing Koiso's paintings, so I was disappointed.
However, there is no doubt that it is a good museum, as the atelier has been relocated and there are explanations from the museum staff.
Also, I would like to take revenge and re-evaluate.

data.formatted_address: 2-2 Hatobachō, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan
data.name: Kobe Maritime Museum

reviews.text: Highly recommend to visit this place. Flight simulation (booking might be required). We managed to put our names on a waiting list and were given time to come back. Jet ski, motorcycles, robots in action and more. Kids loved this place. Tickets are very easy to by on entrance.

It is an educational place for kids to spend about 2 hours, it is located by the harbor. Upon entering, you are greeted with a model of ship from yesteryears, surrounded by smaller models of ships with great importance.

As you move along, you'll see the history of the Kawasaki Industry (from Kobe) including Shinkansen Model 0 to container ships to motorcycles. There are some arcade games involving riding bikes and jet skis as well as a train conductor simulator. Near the end of the exhibition is an automated robot assembling on command.

I went for Miku Exhibition.

Place was closed when we arrived, so could post much about it except the exterior view. Nevertheless, managed to capture BE KOBE and the surroundings at this port. Very calm and serene place to be at, especially when the weather is nice and cool.

Amazing display of model ships and maritime items. One of the largest I've ever seen. The ship driving simulator was so much fun. Well worth the trip and highly recommended. Please note, the building is shared with the Kawasaki Museum which I high recommend as well and has many interactive robots, booths, kiosks and games.
Really enjoyed this museum! Half of it is miniatures and models of ships; the other half is a Kawasaki display. There are games, displays, and wonders!

data.formatted_address: 3-chōme-1-2 Ōjichō, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0838, Japan
data.name: Kobe City Museum of Literature

reviews.text: it’s a great pleasure to visit this place!
This house is birthplace of KANSEIGAKUIN!
No Giant Panda available

This free facility was originally a Kwansei Gakuin building. Write your name on the list at the entrance.
The room has the characteristic smell of a place with a lot of old books.

I could see a building with a retro atmosphere from the 4th floor of the Tadanori Yokoo Museum of Contemporary Art, and I was intrigued and stopped by. This structure was the starting point of Kwansei Gakuin. The Kobe Literature Museum is a chapel that was built in the early Meiji period as a symbol of the school and is still the oldest wooden church building in Kobe city. There was a great atmosphere inside the building.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒650-0047 Hyogo, Kobe, Chuo Ward, Minatojima Minamimachi, 1-chōme−５−２ 3階
data.name: The Japanese Museum of Anesthesiology

reviews.text: A free museum with exhibits that show the history of anesthesia from the time when it was not yet recognized as a medical science to the present day.When I visited, there were no other visitors.In the back there is an exhibit where you can operate a real anesthesia machine. Yes, I was able to touch the ventilator's power supply and adjust the amount of oxygen.

Understand the history of anesthesia. The chronology and exhibits are easy to see and wonderful. It was fun though.
It is okay to use the photos for personal use.

It is the only museum in Japan run by an academic society.
The exhibits include things related to anesthesia, from drugs and medical equipment used in the past to modern equipment.
If you are interested, I think you will enjoy it.
There are almost no visitors, so you can take your time to look around each one, so I highly recommend it!

There are no conspicuous signs or anything, so it's hard to find...
It is located on the 3rd floor of the Kobe Kimec Center Building.
If you meet the staff, you can receive a Hello Kitty keychain.
It's not big, but it's free, so I think it's worth visiting at least once.

There were exhibits of old and present operating tables and past anesthesia machines.
After that, there was a chronology of anesthesia, the name of the doctor, etc...
I just felt like I was being told a tale of heroism.
There were a few empty old anesthetic boxes on display, but there were only a few at the bottom, and I thought it would be nice to display them higher up and display more vintage empty boxes.
For me, I wanted to know more about why anesthesia works, rather than stories of heroism (as long as I know what I know now).
However, I would love it if visitors could receive an original clear file with Hello Kitty in nurse style and a cell phone strap.It seems like they are only available at the museum.
I learned that opium and chloroform were used as anesthetics in the past...I guess?

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒650-0046 Hyogo, Kobe, Chuo Ward, Minatojima Nakamachi, 7-chōme−１−１ アシックス本社ビル
data.name: Asics Sports Museum

reviews.text:
If you're an Asics fan, or even a sports history fan, this is a great place to view the history of Asics, see famous shoes over its history, and the players that wore and wear them today.  There's also an exhibit that through a small track, lights and audio, show you how fast different sports are played at including the speed of a sprinter that'll blow your mind.

It's just a museum and there's not much else around the area. Given this and that we went on a weekday, there were no other visitors.  This made staff extra friendly although they left us alone after introducing and explaining things.

Note that you can't take photos inside.
Can't take pictures inside the museum, has a lot historical introduction of shoes. No entry fee but better registered before you go there.

Made mini Sports shoes with an instructor who could guide us through the process. Mostly in Japanese but plenty of visual cues and basic instructions to help complete the task. If you're a maker I'd recommend this to you.

If you love to see how Asics and Onitsuka Tiger become what they are today & a fan of marathon and baseball, it’s a good place to start. other than that, you don’t have to visit a man made island in the middle of a few big companies.
Don’t have to come at the exact time of reservation but must be within the slot.

Great museum for everybody who loves sports and people.
Just need an appointment done online and it's for free

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒650-0003 Hyogo, Kobe, Chuo Ward, Yamamotodōri, 1-chōme−7−１６ ダルビッシュコート 3F
data.name: Darvish Museum

reviews.text: Small place but very interesting stuff.
Visited with Kobe Sightseeing Smart Pass. I had a lot of fun seeing real dolls and playing virtual games. I was surprised that my 6 year old daughter hit a home run (lol)

Why Darvish in Kobe? I thought so, but it seems that the building is owned by Darvish's father.
I was very satisfied with the content as it was inexpensive and had a lot of content (there were many valuable items such as equipment that he had actually used, WBC invitation letters, and autographed balls).

It took me about 20 minutes to look around inside, but I had so much fun taking photos of so many things.
They also sell a small amount of goods, such as notebooks and pads, which may be more expensive. It was so cheap I thought.
I thought it was a very conscientious facility.
If you are a baseball fan, we recommend that you stop by once.

It wasn't that big, it felt like a small museum. The entrance fee is 500 yen per adult, but it's worth it because there are many valuable items. I looked at it quite carefully and spent about 30 minutes there. I'm surprised at how realistic the dolls are.

I thought I would visit Japan when they became number one in the world in the WBC, and since they became number one in the world, I went there.
When I went there, it was Yu Darvish's museum, so I saw his career history, and I think it's really amazing that he is a superstar and is still active in the major leagues.
Admission fees are 500 yen for adults, 300 yen for middle school and high school students, and 10 yen for elementary school students, so I think it's cheap.

*In the last photo, when you visit the museum, you can enter a lottery for free, and as souvenirs you will receive 2 paper sheets, 2 clear files, and 1 picture postcard.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒658-0032 Hyogo, Kobe, Higashinada Ward, Kōyōchōnaka, 2-chōme−９−１ 神戸ファッションプラザ 1F
data.name: Kobe Artists Museum

reviews.text: Very interesting architecture. The building looks like the Discovery space ship from Star Trek.
Nice museum !

July 2024
I saw the Mio Hashimoto exhibition.

First of all, I only saw the Mio Hashimoto exhibition at the Kobe Museum of Art, so I don't know what the museum is all about.
The 4 stars are based on the limited space available.
The rating is generally good.
It was held there
“Mio Hashimoto Exhibition”
It was a star ★★★★★.

Sunny day in the rainy season
Although it was a very hot day, the event venue was well air-conditioned and I was able to tour around comfortably.

It was also introduced on TV
Mr. Hashimoto's sculpture
On TV, only a small part of it was introduced, but when I saw the many works and the real thing, I couldn't help but sigh.It was no longer sculptures, but living animals. This is a group of works.

I think it's a very realistic and satisfying viewing event, even for animal lovers who like dogs and cats, and it will remind you of the cats and dogs you once owned.

I think it will be very stimulating for students who are involved in drawing or art, and I'm sure they will be healed along with other animal lovers.

I came on a date with my wife, and she and I both love cats.
I really enjoyed it and was very satisfied.

I took the JR train from my home in Amagasaki, but I transferred twice and got to Rokko Island smoothly without having to walk far from the station.

As soon as you get off at Island Center Station, you will see the Kobe Museum of Art right next to it.

There are convenience stores and Saizeriya, so I want to check out the museum's events and come back!
The museum was a place that made me think.
thank you very much!

I visited Tomio Hashimoto at the exhibition.
My first time in Rokko Island.
The inside of the museum was spacious and had a very quiet atmosphere, and even though there were many items on display, the space was spacious and spacious.

The staff were also very kind and answered any questions I had.
There is a hotel and a restaurant on the same premises, so if you get tired, you can have a coffee time and have a fulfilling day.
The directions from the station tell you to walk outside once, but if you don't overlook the instructions on the floor, you can walk all the way in a covered area.
I found it on the way home, so I think I'll pass by there next time.
It's the passage on the left after exiting the ticket gate.
They always hold good exhibitions. This year, it's Maruko-chan. I remember when I was a student, the song was a big hit.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒650-0041 Hyogo, Kobe, Chuo Ward, Shinkōchō, 7−１, Stage Felissimo, 2F
data.name: Felissimo Chocolate Museum

reviews.text:
The museum is essentially 3 rooms. One room is a hall of neatly presented chocolate boxes. The second room is three giant chocolate bar models for social media purposes. There are curtains and random books in the room about chocolate. The lady with glasses manning the room was nice. The third room is more chocolate boxes presented in an atheistically pleasing way. There are also random models made out of chocolate boxes.

The whole exhibit is 10 minutes; 15 minutes if you take some time.

The gift shop has a very limited selection with high prices.

I would only recommend this place for people who are seriously passionate about the design of chocolate boxes. Everyone else should save the 800Y.

Complete waste of time. Expected to see and learn about chocolate. Instead the museum displays only empty chocolate packaging. The 800¥ charge is also utterly shameless considering that you can walk through in 2 minutes. Do not recommend.
Very small. Just an exhibition of stylish chocolate packages from around the wirld.
Paying 1000 yen to see old chocolate packaging is not worth it.
It's a place you shouldn't go even if it's free.

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-5-21 Mikage, Higashinada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 658-0047, Japan
data.name: Sera Museum

reviews.text: Admission fee is 400 yen. A stylish Western-style building located in the residential area of ​​Kobe Mikage. In addition to art exhibitions, various music concerts and workshops are also held here.

Tastes vary (I think women will like it). The walls are decorated with Mr. Koiso's paintings, and the atmosphere feels more like coming to the house of a nearby piano teacher and drinking tea than an art museum.

I went there several times (✿・ω・)
Not only flower paintings but also Kutani ware etc.
It was created.
This is a work that soothes the soul (♥Ü♥)

A concert will be held at the salon. It's a very nice space.
There is a paid TIMES parking lot (11 spaces) behind this building.
Although it is small, it has a pleasant atmosphere.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-7-20 Utashikiyama, Tarumi-ku, Kobe, Hyogo 655-0037, Japan
data.name: Kobe Doll Museum

reviews.text: Very intricate selection of porcelain dolls.
Love it and worthy to visit

The first floor is a store.
The second and third floors are a museum.
Although it has an eerie feel to it, you can also see the skills of the good old craftsmen.
Autometa is also a must-see.
If you are interested, please come!

Photography is prohibited. There are many dolls and rare dolls on display, but the scale of the exhibits is not large, so unless you are a doll lover, you may find it a bit pricey.
The 2nd and 3rd floors of the 3-story building are occupied by a museum, and you have to climb up and down steep stairs, so it might be difficult for people with walking disabilities or the elderly.
The first floor is a doll shop, and the second floor is where you can see a variety of dolls. Duffy clothes were also on sale. I felt happy to see so many cute dolls.

data.formatted_address: 6-chōme-6-2 Minatojima Nakamachi, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0046, Japan
data.name: UCC COFFEE MUSEUM

reviews.text: This museum costs 300 yen to enter and will take most people around 30-60 minutes to walk around. Limited English is written but reasonable English translations are available via a UCC WiFi but you need your phone for this to work. It's reasonably interesting but may not be everyone's cup of coffee.

If you love coffee and have the time to swing around Kobe, definitely visit the UCC Coffee museum. A nice place to learn about the company history as well as other facts about coffee. Pro tip: have a cup at the UCC Coffee Road cafe for some awesome and unique coffee drinks.☕👌😁👍🏽

You can spend 1.5 hour to understand something about coffee there, from the growth of bean, the history and the design of coffee maker...etc
Highly recommend for having a cup of coffee in this museum. The range of choice and also the service will give you a lovely memory!
Interesting story on coffee. Entrance fee includes coffee tasting - 2 baby cups : Mild and strong roast. Upscale cafe next to museum selling UCC coffee.

I loved this place. A short history of coffee and at the end there is a short quiz game and if you will win you will have free entrance.

Moreover you can taste two nice type of coffee (cold or hot depends about the season, in July and August for sure both of them will be cold).

The staff is so kind and so nice.

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-12-1 Mikagegunge, Higashinada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 658-0048, Japan
data.name: Kosetsubijutsukan

reviews.text: Small private museum with professional curators on those selected subjects

Cycling to Mikage to see “Invitation to a Ghostly World” which is being held until the upcoming Golden Week☺
The Kosetsu Art Museum is located in a quiet residential area along the Hankyu Railway.
This is a museum where you can see time passing in a very quiet and beautiful way.
This exhibition featured around 80 Noh masks and Noh costumes from the Umewaka Rokuro family collection, and I was able to take a leisurely look at them.
Each work comes with an easy-to-understand explanation, and I was also surprised at how well preserved it was.
Of course the exhibits are great, but my favorite is the garden.
Beautiful blue maple leaves under clear skies!
Please come out 🎵
It's about a 5 minute walk from Mikage Station on the Hankyu Kobe Line.
There are also nice cafes nearby, so be sure to enjoy lunch there as well.

I went to "Tea Ceremony and Crafts".
The target is Doyu's black raku "Ozan".
I thought how beautiful it looked in the photos, so I went there to see it in real life.
In addition to Huangshan, we were also able to see some truly beautiful pieces such as maki-e inkstone boxes and Ninsei pots.
The garden is beautiful and only 10 people a day can enjoy matcha (with Japanese sweets).
I gave it 4 stars because I was disappointed that I couldn't see the Yellow Mountain that I was looking for up close because it was displayed in a tea room.
The nearest station ``Mikage'' is a quiet place. There are few places to eat on the way to the museum. It may be a good idea to eat at a transfer station such as Sannomiya.

A friend of mine told me that the museum would be closed for a while due to the upcoming ``Tea Ceremony and Crafts'' exhibition, so I just decided to go to Kyoto soon?!I felt like if I didn't take this opportunity, I would be missing out!So I decided to add an extra night and visit. I arrived in Kyoto on December 7th, and on the morning of the 9th, I went to Kyoto → Shin-Osaka → got off at Sumiyoshi Station. I was curious to see the soft sunlight for the first time.I walked past the pleasant shopping streets of Mt. I stepped into another world while admiring the scenery ♪ Although the coronavirus pandemic was still in progress, there were only a few visitors, so I was able to take my time to see the precious masterpieces in the museum's collection.The garden stretches from the entrance gate to the building. I was only able to take a walk in the front garden 🍁 The autumn leaves were beautiful and the old man persimmons welcomed me with elegance ♪ I asked the nearby shrine that I would like to visit again someday, and on my way home I returned home before the lashu 🏠
*I'm glad I made it on time♪

Xiao Bai now? I saw Shoutoshi Suzuki
800 yen is a bit expensive as there aren't many exhibits and there aren't many pieces that look like Xiao White, but the second half is from the Kyoto National Museum, which looks interesting.
Because it is small, there is no permanent exhibition.

However, considering that the road, gardens, and buildings are nice and you can take your time to see them, I would say it's cheap.

I was impressed by the very classy atmosphere and the lady staff members who wore elegant uniforms and looked like young ladies.

data.formatted_address: 80 Kyōmachi, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0034, Japan
data.name: Kobe Lamp Museum

reviews.text:
A great little museum about the history of lighting and lamps in Japan. The museum itself is on the 3rd floor of the building. There is a cafe on the second. Next to the cafe is a small gift shop which is very expensive.

Almost all the information is in Japanese however the exhibitions are really well presented and it's easy to see what the museum is trying to tell you about its history.

A small museum about Japan lamps and lighting throughout the history from fire making to nowadays electric lamps. The museum is well presented which displays various lamps and the Japanese style paintings regarding to lamps.
Entrance ticket is 200 yen, which is cheaper and much more things to see comparing to the Kobe Lampwork Glass Museum.

Small Museum with a time line format; fire to electric lamps. Amazing collection of lamps with varying shapes and sizes. If you are after a quick cheap stop then definately stop in. English friendly if you have a smart phone with you.
Small museum with displays on histories of lamps from different parts of the world. From the first lamps people use with intricate designs, to our current ones.

I learned about the existence of this facility from a poster of the Tonbotama Museum and visited it.
Commemorative stamps, quiz rallies, and other events are planned so that even beginners can enjoy the event.
Although we only briefly learn about ``light'' at school, it was very interesting to learn about the best things and put them in historical order. The last exhibit on Kobe's recovery made me so emotional that I cried.

I will be very sad when it closes at the end of February. It's a very nice exhibit, so if you've never been, I highly recommend you check it out.

data.formatted_address: 122-1 Higashimachi, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0031, Japan
data.name: Kobe Pearl Museum

reviews.text: Historical building. Good to visit and it's free! You can learn about pearls and it's existence in Kobe. Some explanation are in English
Small, not too scientific, but free
Permanently closed.

This is a small museum that tells the history of pearl farming around the world and in Japan (Kobe). It occupies a section of an old building that was built about 70 years ago, and admission is free. I went because it was closing in March 2023, but it was extremely empty.
Although the content is geeky, such as how pearls are cultivated and how they are sorted, it was quite interesting to learn about some aspects of history. At one time, Kobe was responsible for 80% of Japan's pearl trade. If you would like to know more about the port city of Kobe in the past, please come here.
I don't know if they're doing this now, but apparently there was a service where if you donated around 1,000 yen to a pearl culture, you could receive a small pearl that couldn't be used as jewelry.
It looks like the building will be demolished after it closes, so if you're interested, you should get there as soon as possible.

As soon as you enter the building, there is no reception and you can immediately enjoy the exhibits for free.

I didn't know anything about the history of pearls in Kobe, so it was very interesting, and the exhibits broadened my perspective.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒651-0056 Hyogo, Kobe, Chuo Ward, Kumochichō, 1-chōme−4−７ ＫＯＢＥ ＬＡＮＤＭＡＲＫ
data.name: ＫＯＢＥ ＬＡＮＤＭＡＲＫ

data.formatted_address: 1 Chome-5 Higashikawasakicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0044, Japan
data.name: Harbor Walk

reviews.text: Nice view of Kobe skyline from the water. Easy relaxing walk. And this is not a “hiking trail”, just a paved path on the waterfront.

If you are tried from shopping in Kobe harborland, you can come to this area to relax yourselves. Here you can see the shipyard on the opposite side and potentially able to see submarine. Once you reached the edge, there is a beautiful view of the whole harbor area. The night view is also amazing if you look towards the Marine Time Museum and the Oriental Hotel. Recommended to have a short walk here if you visit Kobe.
Excellent to walk with your couple and/or kids
Nice shopping area, can be a little overwhelming with the different shopping malls and stores. But the lighting along the street was nice, and there was an Old Spaghetti Factory! !
Not many tourist here, harbour view is amazing,  but beware of wind and rain, and there is tour ship(concerto) in the harbour, you can enjoy kobe from tour ship.

data.formatted_address: Kitarokkō-4512-98 Rokkōsanchō, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0101, Japan
data.name: Rokkosan Country House

reviews.text: Best place for kids AND adult to play with snow. You can ski,snowboarding and play sledge. Able to rent all equipment there. Boots, glove, snowboard and etc. There's is kiosk that sell hot drinks and food (NON HALAL)

A large space, for a fee, where you can practice various activities. I came to see the art on the hill. I recommend wearing comfortable shoes and being fit, because you have to "climb" the hill and there are various stairs. Chair lift hardly ever works, I came twice and both times it didn't work. There is also a lake where you can feed the fish (¥ 100)

There is free parking right in front of the entrance. If you want, you can get to the Garden Terrace from here.

Went there with nearly no people, but I got myself a glimpse of what it would be like in a lively day. Tons of activities to get you rollin. The weather, view, activities, ya know. You could spend a whole day there, seriously.
So peaceful and have cute animals.
Nice place for kids to roam around and run freely. Equipped with BBQ area with rentable tools and you can purchase meat/seafood too. Need reservation though

data.formatted_address: 3 Chome-1 Ojicho, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0838, Japan
data.name: Kobe Ōji Zoo

reviews.text: The Panda was not there :( it passed away. Yet, great way to entertain the kids, wish the animals had more space to walk around, a few of them looked stressed.

Quiet day to view with beautiful Sakura Trees everywhere. Went on a Monday morning, most animals were napping at that time. Found out Tan tan (panda) passed away from heart disease March 31st 2024.

Lots of empty stalls.
Lots of memorial plaques commemorating animals that passed away.

Most cats are not on display due to potential Covid exposure.
No Gorillas or otters for multiple reasons.

The facility was very clean and had plenty of bathrooms, seating areas, and vending machines.

The animal are lovely. The place is clean and well maintained.
The price is cheap compared to other animals parks.
If you want a relaxing weekend combined with a walk around the park, this is the place for you.

Kobe Oji Zoo. really enjoyed my day in the morning. Wanted to see the tan tan the panda but she not in due to diagnosed with heart disease. I wish her get well soon ❤️ 💜 ❤️ 🎍 There is a amusement park to enjoy but I didn't go. Looks very fun especially for childrens. Their is a shop and cafes down the road.

Perfect experience!!! Little animals are out instead of in the cage. You can literally see them very close and feel the Mother Nature. They have many super cute but rare animals. I love they put cute rat and cougar at the same place. Japanese Ironic and cute!

data.formatted_address: Nunobiki Reservoir, Fukiaicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0058, Japan
data.name: Nunobiki Reservoir

reviews.text: Some folks call it Nunobiki Reservoir, others say Nunobiki Dam, but either way, it's a pretty cool spot to visit!
Good but not best
Fresh air and beautiful view...

The stairs were steep to get there, but once we got there, the view was open, the sky was close, and there was no wind, so the reflection of the pond like a mirror was mystical. You can feel refreshed within a few minutes walk from Shin-Kobe Station. I went on a weekday before the autumn leaves, and I felt that there were many people walking lightly towards Nunobiki Falls. It's a good exercise for people who don't get enough exercise. While I was looking at the scenery, I lost my footing and fell down on the way home, so this is also a place that taught me that even when visibility is clear, I have to check my footing carefully as I walk.

The reservoir was built in 1900 and has a super cool retro look. It is said to be the oldest concrete dam in Japan, and was designated as a registered tangible cultural property in 1998. The autumn leaves here are unusually beautiful every year, and it's a spot where you can stop and take tons of photos along the zigzag slope.

data.formatted_address: Kitarokkō-4512-150 Rokkōsanchō, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0101, Japan
data.name: Rokko Alpine Botanical Garden

reviews.text:
Rokko Alpine Botanical Garden is not so large as Kobe Municipal Arboretum but the distance is not so much with few minutes drive to the West on Rokko Driveway.  From 10 o'clock spending at the former place (parking fee is 2,000 yen) and taking lunch at the latter one(500 yen for parking) is a planning to kill all day.
Trying Hireso-shot with Olympus OM5 on a tripod, only 2 to 3 m breezing prevented me from good result. 4X magnification by means of Minolta MD Macro 100mm/f4.0 on MFT format invites unexpected difficulty to obtain High Resolution shooting, the period of getting accustomed to an inexperienced condition is required. In spite of countermeasure for close focusing by focusing rail, the result was so far from my initial idea. Overcoming the effect of Object Movement is the first---no wind condition such as flower house is ideal?

These gardens are not super large, but well landscaped, and the autumn colours added to the appeal.  It is also worth noting that the bus stop for the entry is at the park's highest part, meaning there are quite a few stairs to go down.  But you don't have to leave the same way, as at the other end of the park you are close to the previous bustop anyway.

It is well worth a visit on the way to the ropeway cable car to Arima.

The botanical garden is located at the top of Mount Rokko. If you pick up the tourist pass from the tourist center at Umeda station in Osaka it covers free unlimited bus rides on Mount Rokko. Entry is cash only and with the tourist pass you get entry for about 430 JPY which would otherwise cost you around 620 JPY without the tourist pass. 30 mins here is good enough as the garden is not that large. Been to much larger botanical gardens elsewhere but if you want some quiet time - you could easily spend as much time as you want. The 3 star rating is for the size of the garden and not the experience.
The time we went there it was rather cold. So other plants were already wilting. Trees looked beautiful with their autumn colors, i think its best to visit here on spring time

Peaceful place with beautiful scenery of flowers. I visited it in summer season but as it began to rain, the fog became so thick. Really hard to see the scenery. But I really enjoy being in the middle of the mist because it was the first time for me.

data.formatted_address: Yamagori Fukiaicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0058, Japan
data.name: Nunobiki Dam

reviews.text: Nice little hike. Has some sections that elevate similar to stairs. There are also stairs on a few sections of the path. Good first hike in Kobe. Lovely view of the city. Take a water bottle with you.

Great walk from Shin Kobe. We walked with our small luggage rucksacks and had lunch by the dam. Took about 35 minutes to the reservoir.
From inside the station simply take the elevator or escalator  from the main station area with the shops and ticket machines down one floor. The walk passage under the station goes from the left side of the lower level as you face the city, (the north-eastern end).
Good lookout over Kobe on the way up. Large walking area (see map) beyond the dam. We'll come back for a day walk soon.

No view from the Dam / Reservoir but you can get a view from lower down on the path up from Nunobiki waterfalls. There are a couple of benches and the surrounding hills make it a relaxing place to enjoy some quiet away from the city below.
Dam looks amazing in mid Dec. Pretty sure it will look nicer in autumn. Constant cool breeze. Great fresh air.
If you like running go here for a morning run. Just breathtaking!

data.formatted_address: Maruyama Gomo, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0801, Japan
data.name: Nada Maruyama Park

reviews.text: A massive beautiful park tucked into Mount Maya with a breath taking panorama view from Osaka to Kobe port and with a backdrop of the beautiful mountains. On clear days, one can see across the ocean to the Islands beyond. Has a running track, beautiful sakura plus various other flower trees around the running track. It has a play area with slides etc as shown in the pics. Free car parking is available in 2 different parking lots right at the foot of the park and then at the entrance of the park. On holidays it tends to get busy.
It's a nice place to camp, play ball games, and get a nice view of kobe, but be careful! There's nothing in the park but a toilet. Bring whatever you need.
Wonderful park to play balls with kids. Amazing view of Kobe.
Good place with beautiful view of Kobe city…
A great view, spacious grassy field. Not crowded much usually maybe because of the limited parking lot. Cherry blossom season is also recommended.
