reviews.text: Decent theme park that’s safe for little kids.  A lot of the attractions are outdated and rusty, though…
A great family leisure place.  100% pet friendly.  The dog menu is greatly designed.  Perfect for weekend hanging a while day for children and pets; any one should enjoy much here.

Beautiful landscape
Fun go cart
Love this place

Kobe Fruit & Flower Park 道の駅 神戸フルーツ・フラワーパーク大沢 is a large open multi-purpose facility in the north ward of Kobe.

It much more than a park and combines wide open spaces with beautiful flower gardens, fruit picking, a produce market, barbeque area and a hotel with a hot spring (onsen).

Kobe Hotel Fruit Flower building is designed after Rijksmuseum – the Dutch National Museum in Amsterdam. The hotel facilities include the Ozo Onsen, restaurant, swimming pool (summer season) and a gift shop.

Farm Circus is the most recent addition to the park (opening 2017). The concept of Farm Circus is to promote and sell locally grown produce. There is an Italian restaurant, bakery, cafe, learning center and market selling fruit and veg direct to the public.

There are various fruits such as apples, grapes and peaches to enjoy Fruit Picking with the season usually running from late July – late October.

Great for families, the other attractions of Kobe Fruit Flower Park include the Kobe Fairyland Amusement Park, ferris wheel, go carts, putter golf course, playground and multi purpose field.

The car parking and gardens are free. Open times vary between facilities so please check the official website for the correct times
I held barbecue parties there for my スミス英会話  塚口校 students. We bought the food there and cooked the food at our tables. It was very convenient and we had a good time. There were many tables there.

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-3-1 Sannomiyachō, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0021, Japan
data.name: Kobe Beef YAKINIKU Yazawa Honten

reviews.text:
Excellent Dining Experience at 八座和 today.

I recently had the pleasure of dining at  八座和 restaurant and was thoroughly impressed. From the moment I stepped through the door, the staff Mr. Kitano greeted me warmly and made me feel welcome. The hostess was friendly and promptly showed me to my table.

The service throughout my meal was outstanding. My server was attentive, knowledgeable about the menu, and went above and beyond to ensure I had an enjoyable dining experience. They were quick to refill my water, checked in on me regularly, and made helpful recommendations.

The food itself was absolutely delicious. I started with the house salad, which was fresh and flavorful. For my entree, I ordered the grilled salmon, which was cooked to perfection - tender and flaky on the inside with a nice char on the outside. The presentation of the dish was lovely as well.

Overall, I had a wonderful time at 八座和 restaurant. The combination of superb service, excellent food, and pleasant atmosphere made for a truly memorable meal. I would highly recommend 八座和 to anyone looking for an outstanding dining experience. I plan to return again soon.

Best value is the lunch set. Food is good, genuine Kobe beef. Special assortment of beef cut for 3-4 persons is not worth though is nice. The beef white soup is perfect.
Under staff affecting their service.

A great dinner experience! Kitano-san was a great host. They have a variety of kobe beef which tasted amazing alone and with the salt and sauces. The ambience is nice and local, would recommend anyone to visit. Thank you!

The place is great either for families, big group, or couples. We went there for my sister’s birthday celebration and we did not regret it. The wagyu beef is so tender and delicious. Yuri-san (our waiter) is very helpful and accommodating.

A must try when your in Kobe and looking for Kobe beef experience.

I had an incredible dining experience at a 神戶牛燒肉 八坐和 restaurant in Japan. The food was top-notch, with a fantastic selection of high-quality meats and delicious side dishes. The highlight of our visit was the excellent service provided by our waiter, 松阪 (Matsuzaka). He was attentive, knowledgeable, and extremely friendly. Matsuzaka's recommendations greatly enhanced our meal, and his dedication to great service made our visit truly memorable. I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for an outstanding 燒肉 experience. Thank you, Matsuzaka, for making our visit so special!

data.formatted_address: 7-chōme-1-9 Minatojima Minamimachi, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0047, Japan
data.name: 神戸どうぶつ王国(Kobe Animal Kingdom)

reviews.text:
A place good for family. Clean and looks like animals are happy. Except some animals in the cages. Also, you must go to feed the seals. You can also touch the cats and dogs.

Can lunch at park. The food is delicious than expected.

Toilet is clean. Place is clean. Service is good.

I am an artist who's passionate about paintings related to the themes of love, hope, and dreams.

As such, I love looking for inspiration from different places. As my daughter loves animals, we've visited many zoos in Asia and Europe but I had never been inspired by any of them. Every one of them always looked dirty and ill-maintained, and as a result, the animals looked inactive and bored and were asleep most of the time.

Moreover, there were always barriers, cages, and gaps between us and the animals. As a result, I lost interest in visiting zoos in general.

However, this zoo completely changed my perspective. Even though it's relatively small in size, after two hours of wandering around with beautiful animals passing by with nothing separating us, we didn't want to leave!

We were so surprised that all the animals looked happy, clean, and were very active. They even seemed to love posing for pictures! My artistic instincts drew inspiration from the animals. They demonstrated pure happiness, kindness and love for each other. Two pink flamingos were the highlight of the day, as the couple posed together to form a heart shape.

I wonder how the staff treats the animals to keep them happy and contented in their little kingdom? I hope the same care and love would be given to all animals.

- Fang

Mix feelings about this place. There’s both good and bad from my visit.

Good:
The birds and small mammals areas are very well-done. Free flight, setting them into the enclosure which is close to their habitat etc. Seeing animals without a cage is a treat.

Bad:
1. Same feelings as others have mentioned. The bigger mammals area is kind of sad. Seeing wolves and tiger in a place which is even smaller than some birds enclosure without enough enrichment is frustrating. They are amazing animals and could’ve have a very different display than seeing them lying on the floor.

2. I noticed “angel wing” condition on several teals (one is especially serious). I asked a staff if they are aware, and they said they do. This is even more frustrating since angel wing is caused due to nutrition issue, and this teal is still in the pond and receiving all the feed from visitors rather than having a precise diet. I don’t know where to ask about more details, but if someone from animal kingdom saw this, I really would love to know more about how the treatment is in your zoo.

I went to Kobe not because of the famous beef but this animal kingdom. The capybaras are all super cute and adorable. They are not afraid of human at all. So chill. Had such a great time there. And you can pet some of the animals. If you like nature and animals. This is the place you must visit.

Saw tons of animals and they were all so adorable! I didn’t manage to get any tickets for the interactive areas, but all’s good. Do expect lots of school children and families, so crowds are to be expected. The capybara bun from one of the cafes is adorable.

data.formatted_address: 2 Hatobacho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan
data.name: BE KOBE

reviews.text: It was a sunny day. We wanted few pictures here. We had to wait for an hour to get our pictures. There were lots of dog lovers with dogs dressed up cutely so it was fun to watch at them and enjoy the views around. 🙏🏻

Kobe Port becomes a dazzling spectacle at night, particularly around Meriken Park, where modern art installations and sophisticated lighting transform the waterfront into a stunning sightseeing destination. The area is not just a feast for the eyes with its illuminated landscapes; it also serves as a cultural hotspot thanks to the unique art installations that dot the park, making it a great stop for those exploring Kobe after dark.

Despite January's cold, the beautiful night sights of Kobe Port, offers serene and picturesque views that are worth braving the chill for. The park symbolizes Kobe's resilience post the 1995 Great Hanshin Earthquake, combining the waterfront with architectural icons like the Kobe Port Tower and the Kobe Maritime Museum, all brought to life at night by the abundance of lighting. Visitors are encouraged to bundle up and enjoy the breathtaking night views, keeping in mind to take along a extra layers due to port side winds.

Peaceful Oasis: The port area exudes a calming aura, offering a respite from the city's hustle and bustle. The gentle sea breeze, coupled with the mesmerizing views of the waterfront, creates an atmosphere of utter tranquility.

Scenic Beauty: The picturesque landscape surrounding Kobe Port is nothing short of breathtaking. Whether it's a leisurely stroll along the promenade or simply sitting by the water's edge, the stunning vistas of the harbor and mountainside never fail to captivate.

Relaxation Galore: The port area boasts a variety of delightful spots to unwind. From quaint cafes offering a perfect cup of coffee to serene parks ideal for a peaceful read or reflection, every corner seems tailor-made for relaxation.

Cultural Experience: Embracing both modernity and tradition, Kobe Port effortlessly blends contemporary architecture with historical remnants. Exploring the maritime museums and iconic landmarks provides an enriching experience, adding depth to this already serene retreat.

Overall Sanctuary: My visit to Kobe Port was an absolute delight. It's an oasis of calm in the heart of Kobe, inviting visitors to unwind, rejuvenate, and appreciate the serene beauty that surrounds this waterfront haven.

No trip to Kobe is complete without stepping foot here. lol. Although the weather was cloudy and cold, the port side view of Kobe was still enchanting to say the least. Kids running around, pets being walked about, joggers doing their runs, couples snapping their selfies away - everything just gives you the Kobe vibe that you won't get in other cities in Japan!

It will be definitely regretting if you don’t come here!
Spacious harbour with magnificent views, grab a hot latte matcha from Starbucks, sitting at the bank nearby the iconic BE KOBE, sip a bit of matcha, under cold weather, observing people spending life there, things can’t be better!

data.formatted_address: 6 Chome-4 Kanocho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0001, Japan
data.name: The Memorial and Recovery Monument

reviews.text: 1.17 Light of Hope, a place to remember the Great Hanshin Earthquake which happened at January 17, 1995. This light of hope also becoming one of the spot for installation of the light during Casa Armonica 2022. Many people were usually gather here, bring lantern and wrote their hope for the past earthquake. There is a nonstop fire which symbolizes for the hope. This place also near a famous park, Higashi Yuenchi park. I came here at night during the Casa Armonica.

reviews.text:
■Meriken Wharf Monument
A stone tower near Route 2 near the north end of Meriken Park in Kobe Port. A stone monument that looks like a gatepost and is about 2 meters high.
There is a round light at the top. It is a preserved ruin of the pier in front of the American Consulate that was built in 1868. It stands in the middle of the sidewalk.

○Two granite slabs are pasted on the east side.
"Meriken Wharf" written vertically, on the other page
In addition to an explanation of the origin of Meriken Pier,
The name of the preservation donor is engraved on it.

They are Yoshio Suzaki and Yonekichi Ono.
It seems that both of them were based in the port city of Kobe.
The president of a trading company and a port worker, details unknown.

There are many names left behind that were relocated, preserved, or erected and donated, such as the Kobe Naval Training Center Ruins Monument, the Mutsu Munemitsu Memorial Monument, the Strolling Cow Statue at Tug of War Tenmangu Shrine, the Meriken Jizo statue, and the Hyogo Prefecture Milestone Marker.

○ “Kobe Customs Mankoku Wharf” written vertically on the north side
A bronze sign is attached.

●The lights at the top are not lit. Warm-colored lights are lit from the foot of the sidewalk. The open Meriken Park facing the sea was created by reclaiming land between the former Meriken Wharf and Naka Jetty. There are many entrances on each side. Few people stop by this monument during the day.

There is a text that says that Mr. Yonekichi Ono was the head of an organization called the Japan Anchor Boys, and a signboard with his name Shigeto Mukai can be seen next to the Hyogo prefecture mileage marker.What kind of person was he?

Despite the large number of donations, their names do not appear in gentleman's directories or bibliography dictionaries.The government office that accepted the donations has never met anyone who knows about them.The Hiroshima conflict, a model for ``war without humanity'', is the story of Yamaguchi-gumi and Honda-kai. A direct conflict was feared, but with the mediation of Shigeto Mukai, a powerful man at the Port of Kobe who was a brother to the top leaders of both organizations, the situation was brought to an end. Yoneyoshi may have been Mukai's pocket sword.

Is there anyone who knows about the Japan Anchor Boys? We may be able to get a hint why the Kobe Naval Training Center ruins monument is shaped like an anchor.

The anchor-shaped design placed on the top square of this stone tower (stone monument) may have been an anchor-shaped design favored by Yonekichi at the time of donation.It is also possible that an origin plate and lighting equipment were added as part of repairs. I look at it, but I don't know the history.
Monument of the ruins of Meriken Wharf, commonly known as Meriken Wharf.
It was just standing there, but I could feel the history.
There's a Bentley next to it.

reviews.text:
▼When you hear the name Naval Training Center, many people think, ``Oh, it's Ryoma Sakamoto!'' This famous place is located between the Minato and Motomachi downtown areas of Kobe. (The hotel you can see behind me in the photo is Hotel Okura, and Motomachi is just down the street in front of you towards the mountain (Mt. Rokko).)
▼ ``These days, I became a disciple of the military scholar Katsuraintaro Daisensei, and he was loved by me...I put on a slightly arrogant face and secretly asked him to come.Ahem, ahem,'' he wrote a humorous letter to his sister. Ryoma Sakamoto, who sent the training center, will go out of his way to raise funds for the establishment of this training center.
▼As stated in the letter, the idea was Kaishu Katsu, a high-ranking official of the shogunate at the time. Kaishu took the 14th Shogun, Iemochi Tokugawa, on board the warship Jundomaru, explained the need for a navy, and obtained permission to open the Kobe Naval Training Center.
▼However, the money donated by the shogunate was not enough to cover the operation of the training center, so Ryoma was able to open it by borrowing 1,000 ryo from Shungaku Matsudaira of the Fukui clan.
▼It seems that the ``ahem, ahem'' letter I mentioned earlier was written right after this construction was completed, but even though Ryoma was just a ronin, he was truly a man with great mediation skills.
▼This naval training center was opened by Kaishu Katsu as its director for the purpose of operating the Kanrin Maru, a warship of the Shogunate. Kaishu Katsu was also an interesting person, and in this small fishing village, he would like to thank the people who took care of him. ``The Shogunate will succumb to external pressure, and Kobe will eventually open a port in this area. Buy the land now,'' he said, a statement that could hardly be believed to be from an important member of the Shogunate. Those who actually bought the land ended up making a lot of money (lol).
▼Furthermore, although they were important members of the shogunate, they also attracted many anti-shogunate patriots. Well, you can see it by looking at the way he has faith in Ryoma Sakamoto.
▼When the ``Kinmon Incident'' broke out in Kyoto, the shogunate saw the fact that there were many anti-shogunate patriots as a problem and closed the training center. Kaishu Katsu was dismissed from office, and Ryoma and others were sheltered by the Satsuma clan.
▼Then, Ryoma made use of his experience at this training center and established Kameyama Shachu in Nagasaki with funding from Satsuma Domain's Tomoatsu Godai and others. As you all know, this would develop into the famous Kaientai.
▼It’s the remains of a huge dream! Kaishu Katsu, Ryoma Sakamoto, and others at the end of the Edo period. I felt that Kobe was naturally bright (lol).
Kaishu Katsu's Kobe residence was located near the Kobe Naval Training Monument and Kobe Gion Shrine.

The journey to follow in the footsteps of Ryoma Sakamoto is very interesting.

Just a quick thought
Kochi
Kyoto
Nagasaki
Kobe
Tokyo

Good for those days, good for you!
Japan is large
The world is also big.

Here in Kobe, there was a training center where Kaishu Katsu was the director and piloted the Kanrin Maru. It is said that there were about 300 trainees.

However, in 1864, the ``Kinmon Incident'' occurred in Kyoto, and the shogunate was forced to close the school because anti-shogunate roni were among the trainees.
Also, Kaishu Katsu has also been fired!

The students here must have been highly motivated and engaged in daily training and lectures.

While looking at this stone monument, I remembered the time when even small-time workers went to seafaring school, although the times were different, and I felt sorry for the difference in their aspirations.

I think we probably studied about the same content for about half of the courses then and now, but our aspirations, drive, and guts were completely different.

Every day at my small job, I kept thinking, ``I'll finish it early~💦'' and ignored class.

The seniors are amazing!

I never got to the point where learning is fun.

reviews.text:
It is the best of Tadao Ando's places.  He focused on the harmony achieved when light, water, and sky meet architecture.

This is where those harmonies are best expressed.  This is the place where you can get to know Tadao Ando best.

There is also a gallery containing his buildings.  The museum itself was also designed by him.  wonderful sky.  Clean air.  Kobe's sea.  Intense sun.  The sky seen through the slits in the building.

I can't find a single regret.  Walking from Nada Station to the museum also provides two views.

I recommend walking in different directions when coming and going.  You must stay in the museum for at least one hour.

The amazing thing is, it's free.

Take the elevator at the north exit and see the mountain-side observatory on the 4th floor.  The apple photo taken from the 4th floor is also good.

I visited it one the second Sunday in the month so it is free for some exhibitions. The most signature landmark is the green apple and deserve to take a picture with it. I love the vibe of the museum. Everyone are quiet and focus on the picture. You can take a look of it because it also near the ocean.

𝗟𝗔𝗟𝗜𝗦𝗔 | 𝘔𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘮𝘢𝘭 ‧ 𝘈𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘵𝘪𝘤 ‧ 𝘗𝘭𝘢𝘤𝘦𝘴

Instagram: @lalisa_doniho
Links: http://linktr.ee/lalisa.doniho
__

The area is quite huge and it has three floors of exhibition. However, you will have to keep your stuffs in the locker. They have paintings, mixed-media, statues, architectures and also a few digital media too. You can see a river view outside and a souvenir shop too. There is no snack, food, or drink stalls here.

Great Art Museum where you can enjoy a good selction of art work and beautiful architecture.

We only entered the permanent exhibition area, but it was enough to occupy us for hours. The curator did an excellent job in selecting a wide variety of art pieces from both local and international artists feature both modern and classic work. Lighting, framing, and placement of the work are done really well. We especially like Western style painting by Japanese artists, which offer a unique blend of east and west.

I saw Tadao Ando works from the photos many before, but this was the first time i experienced his work up close. Now i understand why this self-taught architect has received so much fame and praise. The simple design, material selection, and use of space provide a zen like experience.

We visited the museum in the late afternoon, and the sun was setting by the end of our tour. So It was lovely to walk along the river watching the sun set. It took us around 2 hours to explore both art and Ando museums, but because we have a plan for dinner. Otherwise, we could have spent more. However, if you have no time, 1.30 hours should be enough.

The ticket cost 500 jpy for the permanent exhibition and 1800 jpy for special exhibition or 2100 jpy for the combined ticket.

data.name: Kobe Center for Overseas Migration and Cultural Interaction

reviews.text: Small, cozy museum, free admission. Located in building formerly used to process and hold emigrants before leaving Japan for various South American countries, of which Brazil was the most frequent. Informative photo and poster exhibits are written in Japanese, Portuguese and English. Upstairs bedrooms were recreated. Exhibits are unstaffed. They include oral history interviews of descendants stillliving in Brazil and film taken in the 60s and 70s of emigrants leaving Kobe. The presence of staff or volunteer docents would make viewing the exhibits immensely more meaningful and valuable to visitors. Uncertain if emigration records are available upon inquiry. A must visit for anyone with relatives who emigrated from Japan to South America.

*Tá rolando exposição da turma da monica até 28/08* It's free and it's a good place to know about the history of emigration of Japaneses to many countries, specially to Brazil, which is the biggest population of descendants in the world.

1999-2007
CAP HOUSE appearanceIn November 1999, the NPO Art and Planning Council (CAP) commissioned by the city of Kobe began its activities as an art space based on the idea of ​​"artist in registration (artist with life)". The bedroom of "Immigrants" has been revived as an atelier where artists are engaged in creative activities, and various public events such as exhibitions, concerts, lectures, and forest schools were held as well as creative activities. At the same time, the Kobe Emigration Reference Room was set up on the 1st floor, and the 4th floor became an activity base for the Kansai Brazilian community. Looking back on the history of immigrants, support activities for Nikkei have begun. As these activities continued, voices calling for permanent preservation were raised from local Japanese organizations in Brazil, and the National Overseas Nikkei Kaikan Promotion Council was established with the Japan-Brazil Association as the center, and the prefectures and cities were established. Discussions involving the country and petition to the country were developed.

2007-2009 In
2007, with the cooperation of the national and prefectural governments, the city of Kobe decided to preserve and redevelop the building of the former Kobe Migration Center. Construction was declared on April 28, 2008 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the migration to Brazil, and construction began in May of the same year and was completed in June 2009. The opening ceremony was held on June 3, 2009, and it has three functions: "Plaza for embarking on hope and the unknown," "Plaza for coexistence with multiculturalism," and "Plaza for creation that makes the most of art." It started as a cultural exchange center.

A very good place to study history of Japanese migration.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒650-0024 Hyogo, Kobe, Chuo Ward, Kaigandōri, 3-chōme−1−１ 神戸中華総商会ビル 2F
data.name: Kobe Overseas Chinese History Museum

reviews.text: 300 yen to see one small room with mostly photos and papers.

I learned about Ryotaro Shiba's ``Kaido wo Yuku'' and visited here.
Sun Yat-sen's ``Philanthropy'' and Director Aishin Wing's ``Landing Root'' tell us everything.
Personally, I remember being surprised when a female student with the surname Wu announced in Kobe that she would become a barber instead of going to high school.
Many of the clothesmakers who used scissors were from the Shanghai area.Western culture had been imported with the opening of the port after the defeat of the Opium War, so the signboard of ``Shanghai Tailor'' was used in settlements. It flourished with Westerners living there.
At first, Chinese food was disliked because it was too greasy, but after the war, the taste was improved to appeal to Japanese people, and it flourished.
Many people working in the barber industry, which uses razors, were from Jiangsu province. Because they were so busy that they couldn't even eat, their children did not follow in their footsteps, and as a result, the only business in Sanba that continues to prosper today is the cooking business of ``Hato'' (kitchen knives). ” (summary of explanation)

On the second floor of a building called the Kobe Chinese General Chamber of Commerce, west of the Nanjing Town Archway, the museum introduces the establishment of the first batch of Chinese from China. At that time, there were the Fujian Public Office of the Fujian Clan and the Sanjiang Public Office of the Sanjiang Clan ( The Yangtze River Delta region was mainly composed of immigrants from the Jiangsu, Zhejiang and Hubei regions). Later, they funded the anti-Qing movement in their home country and also made great contributions to Sun Yat-sen’s Revolution of 1911. This was Sun Yat-sen's base camp in Japan at that time. The Kobe branch of the Chinese Kuomintang had a great influence. Interestingly, Sun Yat-sen also appointed a Kobe Chinese as the Minister of Transportation. During the Sino-Japanese War, the number of Chinese was greatly reduced, and the Chinese in Japan had to endure the discriminatory policies in the war environment. At that time, the overseas Chinese in Fujian even staged an uprising. Most of the collections are overseas Chinese calligraphy and paintings, and one is by Kang Youwei. There are also some old items from the Kuomintang, such as overseas party membership certificates and government approval documents. When Taiwan returned to China in 1945, there were also Taiwanese Japanese who applied for Chinese passport approval. This is a very precious historical material.

After the war, it can be seen from the introduction of the museum that the Chinese in Kobe were also divided into two factions, the Kuomintang and the Communist Party. The schools of the two sides also taught different things. In 1953, there was an incident of overseas Chinese returning to the mainland. I wonder whether these overseas Chinese will be fine after returning. ?

According to the museum staff, you can visit the Sun Wen Museum by taking the subway for about five stops from Kobe Station to "Maiko" station and then walking for five minutes. I went there immediately after finishing.

Tickets are 300, cash only.

Located near Meriken Park. I thought that overseas Chinese people probably played a big role in the development of the port city of Kobe, so I made it a must-see facility. Unfortunately, the exhibits are completely incoherent and we are unable to learn about the achievements of overseas Chinese people. I was disappointed that I had finally found it and visited it.

It is located along the national highway, and the nearest station is Motomachi Station. I entered the class thinking that I had learned about overseas Chinese in social studies class.

It was located in a corner of a building, and the inside of the building had the atmosphere of a company office, so it was difficult to enter.

The exhibits focused on specific individuals rather than on overseas Chinese in general.
I wasn't particularly interested in it, so my impressions are kind of like this, but I thought it was good that it was explained in a neutral manner without leaning into any particular direction.
I felt like the 300 yen admission fee was a big deal.

It’s a Victorian style English building. Built by the British settlers and to date it’s preserved with all the details. They brought a few famous characters from English literature to attract the tourists. The second floor is dedicated to Sherlock the famous English detective with his assistant Watson. It’s pretty crowded in weekends.
Nice house, but the pub is permanently closed now.
Not very big but the Sherlock Holmes exhibition is fascinating - the books brought to life with imagination and humor - and the roses in the garden were in full bloom

reviews.text: It is the largest of the Ijinkans in Kobe and is well worth a visit. Located inside the Kobe Oji Zoo, you can stop by while you're looking at the animals. It is a beautiful building that matches the natural background.

The combination of the zoo, retro amusement park, and old hunter's residence feels strange, but it's really good.
The building is spacious and the colors are cute.

An alien museum located within the Oji Zoo. Although the building is different from that of a zoo, it has a quite impressive appearance.
However, the opening of the interior varies depending on the month, and in July it is only open on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays. On this weekday day, I was only able to look at the exterior.

This historic castle is amazing 🌸
I could see it from the zoo and it felt like I was visiting Kitano Ijinkan.

Originally Kitano Town
A building located in the so-called Ijinkan district
It was moved to this location in 1960.
One of the largest Ijinkan buildings in Kobe
April, May, and October are open to the public.
It is a building that gives you a sense of nostalgia.
Admission fee is included in the Oji Zoo admission fee and is not required.
You will be asked to take off your shoes and change into slippers to tour the room, so you can even go barefoot.
After visiting the first floor, go to the second floor
Pale green gives an exotic feel
Two-story building with distinctive sun terrace

data.formatted_address: Yamagori Fukiaicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0058, Japan
data.name: Herb Museum

reviews.text:
We went here last 2023 January 16. The winter foliage as expected is vastly different and not as beautiful compared to other seasons. Though the place is still charming and quaint. Since we took a cable car ride round trip we were not able to explore more of the surroundings compared to hiking down.

It was really cold as it was windy, good thing the shops were open. We had some coffee and currywurst for snacks.  The gift shop also had nice items on sale.

Overall a good experience. But I think it’s better to visit during the less cooler seasons to fully appreciate the foliage and surrounding sceneries.

The Kobe herb museum was surprisingly a very enjoyable and interesting experience. There is lots to see, smell and taste, making it a must see for any trip to Kobe. We were there at Christmas time when they had a German inspired Christmas market with lots of traditional German food and trinkets. It is reachable by a lift, which is a great attraction itself. I would recommend taking the lift all the way up, then walk to the middle station and go back to the city.

Even though the outdoor flowers in winter are basically non-existent, still a beautiful place with a series of well-arranged greenhouses, a nice view from the cafe, a selection of suitable gifts at the souvenir shop and winter vegetables growing.
Beautiful view and nature. Worth the trip 100%. Just don’t eat there. Waste of money.
Very beautiful views of kobe and the gardens were great even for kids to have fun in!

data.formatted_address: Yamagori Fukiaicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0058, Japan
data.name: Nunobiki Park

reviews.text: Fantastic place worth the hike.  Although my wife and kids were super tired walking up and up & up
Absolutely brilliant. Loved every second no matter how tough it got.

I only had a limited time in Kobe and so I decided to really stick with what I wanted to see which was a lot of nature.

I saw Nunobiki Herb Garden in one online itinerary post and got curious because of its gorgeous flowers. The tram leading up to it was also come-on for me!

It was a great decision. Your adventure starts once you board the tram and you see the spectacle of lush slopes and waterfalls. The upper portion of the gardens is a magnificent scene of a beautiful tiny European-styled village set-off by colorful blooms. The place is Instagram heaven! But, pry yourself away from your camera ( a tough feat, I assure you) and immerse yoir senses in the sights and fragrance of the gardens.

I had a fun time exploring the fragrance hall, the salad gardens (haha) and the greenhouse. The highlight of my visit was the dreamy strawberry cheesecake I had: it came as a pouch made out of mochi dough (I assume) holding a good dollop of cream cheese. It was topped with strawberry slices and drizzled with strawberry sauce. It was heaven.

I would definitely return another time.
I love the hike up. The scenic view was very nice. This hike is not for beginners. It is a steep incline going up. If not, you can take the cable car up. The shop has great gifts.

A good place to get away from the city and either spend some time having a picnic or enjoying a drink and meal on the top. Highly recommend taking the ropeway up to the top and walking down the hill. There's a trail that comes all the way down to Shin Kobe train station if you decide to take a one way ride to the top. There is a water resavoir and waterfall along the trail. It's much easier to walk down from the top, especially during the hot and muggy summer months.

data.formatted_address: Kobeko Jikata, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0007, Japan
data.name: Kitano Trail

reviews.text: Easy casual walk between Kitano and Shin Kobe Station. Nice way to get out of the city and get some fresh air.

There were two groups of overseas tourists. One group had a caster bag, and the other group was empty-handed, so they may have left their luggage in a locker at Shin-Kobe Station.
Did you get a sense of Rokko as a mountain that you can walk to from the city?
However, since it is not paved, it can become slippery due to fallen leaves immediately after rain, so be careful.

Even though it's right behind Shin-Kobe Station, you can really go hiking on the mountain path. I went for a walk from Shin-Kobe Station towards Ijinkan, but even though it was evening, there were no people around and the mountain path was dusted with fallen leaves, so I regretted it a little. It is approximately 1000m to Ijinkan. It was a relatively flat route, similar to hiking, so I didn't feel out of breath and was able to complete it in about 15 minutes.

You can walk from Fubiki-no-Taki to Kitano Ijinkan Street. There is no scenery on the way. Only the observation deck in Kitano has good views. Although it is just on the edge of the city, it feels like being deep in the mountains and valleys. The difference in height is not too big, concentrated at the head and tail.

I went from the Kitanozaka direction.
There is a narrow mountain path from Minato Miharashidai.
The fallen leaves have accumulated quite a lot without rotting and are fluffy. It is best to avoid wearing heels or sandals. (It's also in the notes)
If you follow the path for a while, you will come out under the ropeway.
Honestly, it's a little scary because there are slippery areas and the area is dense.
It's about 1km, so you can go as fast as you like. There is a restroom as soon as you get off the train towards Shin-Kobe.

data.formatted_address: Nagamineyama Mayasan, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0104, Japan
data.name: 神戸市灘区 天狗道展望岩場

reviews.text: Hiking from the shin to mount maya is not the easiest thing to do after sitting on the train from Tokyo but it is well worth it. Bring some water with you and this trail isn’t bad. It’s just a lot if you are not expecting it it. The trail starts east enough but as you go up it becomes more difficult. You will encounter broken stairs, broke rocks, a rock face to climb lots of uphill on rough terrain, and not a lot of other people. You do however get amazing views that make it all worth it and I would do it again in a heartbeat. Bring water and some good shoes or sandals if you are like me and go!

You can get a free hiking map at the station tourism desk.

The view from the top is great and apparently also great at night. You could try to time your route so that you make it to the top around sunset, enjoy the views, then take the ropeway down.

The Old Maya Road is less crowded, but when you look back you can see the Kobe Port, making it my favorite route.

This time, when I arrived at the ruins of Gyoja-do, I received some advice from some veterans who were taking a break, saying, ``I recommend the Maya Alps!'' From there, I changed my route and went along Gyoja Ridge, an exposed rock.

A steep climb up a rocky ridge like Mt. Arachi, a moderate sense of altitude, and a wonderful view. It has quickly become my favorite route.

(As of January 2022)
If you look at the previous post, there is a cylindrical thing that shows the direction, but it seems like it is gone now.
When I got to the tip, the scenery was better and more impressive than I expected.

data.formatted_address: Okusasadani Fukiaicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0058, Japan

reviews.text: Camper paradise.  Pond with crystal clear water.  Kids having fun.
Quiet and peaceful place for bbq and gathering with young boys...
Amazing

I'm glad I went! There were only a few groups of people visiting on a weekday before the leaves turned red, there was no signal (docomo line), the sky was close, and it was refreshing. A lot of insects (winged ants) came. While thinking that humans are interfering with nature. I wonder if there is any insect repellent. It took less than an hour from Shin-Kobe, and since I don't usually get enough exercise, it was quite a difficult climb up and down. But it's a place you'll want to go to again.
...It's coming again (November 25, 2023), the best time to see the autumn leaves, and the temperature seems to be dropping significantly in Ichigahara. There were many children's groups such as the Boy Scouts, which was crowded with people around noon on Saturday.

It was lively with many people setting up tents and having barbecues.
The autumn leaves such as maples around this area were very beautiful and worth seeing.

[2023/12/3]

data.formatted_address: Motoyamachomori, Higashinada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0111, Japan
data.name: Kazafuki Rock

reviews.text:
This is a really good place for a shortish hike. Once you have found the entrance (Ashiya Rock Garden) the start is pretty steep, gaining about 400m in a couple of kilometres, and you do actually need to scrabble up some small, steep sections, but it is really fun. I'd say its okay for kids aged 7 and upwards, though they'll need to be careful. My daughters really enjoy it.

It's a pretty popular place but not crowded. You do need to keep an eye out for wild pigs and snakes. We've seen both on different visits.

From the top of this hike (pictured) you can walk a few minutes further and find a pond full of water-lilies.

If you take a track leading down and west you'll come out near Hankyu Okamoto Stn area. From Hankyu Ashiyagawa Stn to this rock place then down to Okamoto was about 15km, mostly downhill, and took us a couple of hours. You could do it faster but we stopped for breaks quite often and it was intensely hot. The route is virtually all under tree cover.

Fun, but sometimes intense hike up to great views of Ashiya and the Kobe area.  Young children or elderly might have problems as there are some areas accessible only by climbing.  Wild boars are often seen roaming around, and there is a great little restaurant/bar in a cave at the start of the hike! Can be hard to find from Ashiyagawa station.
Wonderful view! Tough for children and elderly as they need to be fit to climb up rock walls, steep stairs to reach this peak
Fantastic view on the way up Rokko.
Just loved this places... Beautiful

data.formatted_address: Nunobikiyama Fukiaicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0058, Japan
data.name: Nunobiki Waterfall

reviews.text: I visited by bicycle. Heading from the city of Kobe towards Nunobiki Falls, the path is always steep, making it quite tough. After parking my bike in a spacious area with a good view of the city, I walked to the location of the falls. It took about 10 minutes to reach the falls on foot. The powerful sound of the roaring water was truly impressive.

Nunobiki Falls, with its proximity to Shin-Kobe Station, offers a convenient nature escape right next to the urban environment of Kobe. The hike to view the falls is relatively age-group friendly, featuring a loop that's short enough for most visitors to enjoy without too much strain. Interestingly, the area is home to a unique mermaid shrine, featuring some folklore to the natural beauty.
Despite a mild snowfall during the visit, which added a serene beauty to the landscape, the falls remain a beautiful sight, even when the water flow is not at its peak.
This combination of accessibility, manageable hiking trails, cultural interest, and seasonal beauty certainly makes Nunobiki Falls worthy to visit when looking for a relaxing day hike.

A beautiful waterfall! I would certainly recommend visiting it as the view is beautiful and even the walk is really nice.

I would recommend taking the advised route and follow the signs instead of taking an alternative route. I took an alternative route and it was quite a steep and challenging walk, i still enjoyed it but for the people that are out of shape you should definitely take the normal route.
Lovely falls and nature walks behind JR Shin Kobe station. You can also connect to Kitano area through the nature walks. Would love to be back for some hikes next time

To go there you need pass the taxi stand tunnel with no pedestrians, which is counterintuitive. But the signs are everywhere both in english and Japanese.
The place is not that remote or hard to reach, the main view is about 15mins walk up the stairs. The place is well lit at night and very safe. You can continue walking up the stairs to see the reservoir.

reviews.text:
It was a good beach to visit while in Kobe in summer. I’m giving it 3 stars though because I have been to better ones. I went there on the first week of September, so that could be a factor why I was not at all wowed by this beach. (I’m from a part of the Philippines where the beaches have white sand and the water is crystal clear, so my standards of a good beach is a little high. Lol)

PROS:

1. Easily accessible. You can easily take a train to Suma Station, which is right in front of the beach.

2. There are shops where you can buy food and drinks. For instance, there’s Grateful’s (burger shop), a conbini bu Suma Station, some vending machines, etc.

3. The water is clear. Not the clearest I’ve seen, but is clear enough.

4. You can see some small fishes.

5. The view is nice.

CONS:

1. The beach is pebbly. If you have a sensitive sole, it’s gonna be an experience for you.

2. When we went there, there was a dead fish on the beach. Not sure if it was washed ashore or because of some bird.
Such a beautiful beach and perfect time of the year.
I went here last spring and I was amazed that the beach has clear and clean water. I was expecting different because the beach was nearby the city. Maybe good for swimming, picnics and fishing.

Fun beach 20 minutes from downtown Kobe. Very convenient and close by from Osaka. Beach wasn't like my home Hawaii but the sand and water was refreshing. Nearby restaurant and bar next to the beach was awesome 😎. Good times and summer vibes. This is my new favorite beach near Osaka. Enjoy and Aloha
Not well maintained. Construction was going on . It’s just in front of suma JR station. One can easily reach from Osaka

data.formatted_address: 2 Hatobacho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan
data.name: Port of Kobe Earthquake Memorial Park

reviews.text:
This memorial, dedicated to the victims of the devastating 1995 Kobe earthquake, is a poignant reminder of the fragility of life and the incredible strength of the human spirit.

Upon entering the park, you are immediately struck by the imposing, twisted steel structures that once were port facilities. These twisted, deformed beams serve as a visceral representation of the sheer force of the earthquake that ravaged this area. Walking among these massive fragments, you can almost feel the weight of the tragedy that unfolded here over 25 years ago.

Interspersed among the destroyed structures are thoughtful, minimalist memorials and contemplative spaces that invite visitors to reflect on the fragility of life, the importance of disaster preparedness, and the power of community and resilience in the face of unimaginable adversity.

One of the most poignant elements is the "Wall of Courage," a simple yet impactful display of handwritten messages from survivors, rescue workers, and others touched by the earthquake. These personal accounts provide a human connection to the tragedy and serve as a reminder that behind the statistics and news reports, there are real people whose lives were forever changed.
This is a lovely park as well as a somber reminder. There's plenty to do and see, and also lots of open space in which to just be.
It was interesting to see, but don't plan to spend more than 10-20 minutes at this memorial.  I was surprised that they were able to preserve the small section of ruin!
A pugnant moment. Let you think of the people who are gone and the resilience of the people who reconstructed this beautiful city.

The park consists of two parts: exhibitions on concrete walls and part of the quay damaged by the earthquake. The exhibition illustrates the damage and restoration of Kobe Port, including pictures and videos. Explanations are in Japanese and English. There is also a round black disc monument representing 05:46, the time of the earthquake.

The relics are a large section of the quay that was destroyed by the earthquake. To prevent further collapse, steel pipes were placed in front of the quay and the space between the pipes. The quay was then filled with stone materials. Ruined concrete walls and tilted lampposts are silent reminders of the earthquake’s shocking power.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒651-1104 Hyogo, Kobe, Kita Ward, Yamadachō Aina, 字田代
data.name: National Akashi-kaikyo Park Kobe Dist. Aina Satoyama Park

reviews.text: A quiet short escapade from Kobe. Only several stops from Shinkaichi Eki through the Kobe Densetsu Line and stop at Aina Eki. Then the hike begins, walk on through scenic route and paddy fields to the entrance. Buzz the intercom, open the gate, 450yen for admission. You've got choices of scenes depending on the season. Also the Traditional Japanese Houses, in which one of them showcases the habitat within the park. And enjoy the nature.

Lovely Summer’s Day. Perfect to play with family and friends.

COME ON ENGLAND!

A facility with an old-fashioned satoyama landscape. You can catch insects, observe plants, and experience farming. I think it's fun for kids. There are no convenience stores or restaurants within the park, so a packed lunch is essential.

Although the scenery within the park itself is a natural scenery that can often be seen in Japan's mountainous regions, I think it would be a good idea to intentionally develop and open the park to the suburbs of Kobe. I think it is meaningful to convey to children the rural landscape of Japan, which will be diminished in the future. When we went there, there were children playing in the stream. As a parent, it may be safer for your child to be able to interact with nature in a miniature park than to have an accident in a natural river that they are not used to playing in. I also heard that they have restored an old Japanese house. When I saw the inside, it was so beautiful that I couldn't help but want to have some tea. I didn't have much time this time, so I went from the Shiawase no Mura side and could only see about half of it, but I would like to visit again someday.

I went there to see the filming locations for Rurouni Kenshin.
It is recommended to use a tramcar rather than walk to get around the area, which has many slopes.
I went on Sunday, June 6th, and it was busier than I expected.
It was easy to understand as there was someone explaining that there were a lot of photos from the shooting site on display. We looked around the rice terraces and the dragonfly pond.

data.formatted_address: Botswana
data.name: Chobe National Park

reviews.text: Must visit park when Botswana not just because is one of the most easily to access, but also because give you the opportunity to spot many different wild animals. I would recommend to do a game drive and not drive yourself if you can.
If you do not come across elephants, you are in the wrong place! An animal lover's dream as there is great wildlife. And if you are a photographer, it's a must see

My visit at Chobe National Park was amazing. This place in entirely nature made because the staff told me they never feed wild animal, or stop there fight, or even clean up elephant corpse.

The landscape is definitely not as beautiful as man made safari, but that is why you should love it. You can see each tree eaten by impalas so they all have very little leaves left at the bottom of the trees. You will see the gorgeous Chobe River as a background too.

Depend on your driver skill, you can see various animal along the way. I saw elephants, lions, boars, impalas, birds. If you love animal, you will love this place a lot.

My safari in Chobe National Park was an extraordinary experience. The landscape was breathtaking, with the Chobe River providing a stunning backdrop. Our guide expertly navigated the park, allowing us to witness a remarkable variety of wildlife. The sight of elephants moving gracefully across the plains at sunset was unforgettable. The abundant birdlife added vibrant splashes of color to the experience. It wasn’t just a journey through nature, but a profound journey into tranquility and awe. Chobe is truly a testament to the beauty and spirit of the wild.

Not the best organized but a great landscape even though in drought conditions. Not too much wildlife spotted on Dawn safari until lion pride spotted at river.  Great close encounter. Evening cruise on Delta was much better.

Great park and many events! We love to go there with our children and dogs.
Also there are sometimes cruise ships from Germany, Netherlands or America. Here was the cruise ship Phönix Reisen from Germany

Has the Be Kobe sign.
Often there are night time fireworks 💥.
Starbucks ☕️ is there.
Some historic structures.
The area is worth  a visit.

It's a large scenic spot with a very comfortable environment.  You can take a walk while enjoying the sea breeze.  There is also a Starbucks nearby.  You can have a hot cup of coffee there.

Meriken Park (メリケンパーク, Meriken pāku) is a waterfront park located in the port city of Kobe, Hyōgo Prefecture, Japan. The park features the Kobe Port Tower, Kobe Maritime Museum, and a memorial to victims of the Great Hanshin earthquake. The name of the park comes from the word "American," which was commonly translated as "Meriken" during the Meiji era.

the park is really big
you can sit on the stairs near the water
the night view is beautiful

data.formatted_address: 4-chōme-1-22 Goshikiyama, Tarumi-ku, Kobe, Hyogo 655-0035, Japan
data.name: Goshikizuka Tumulus

reviews.text:
Near Sanyo-Tarumi station JR.
It’s easy to find.

You need to register your name when you get to the site.
You can ask the staff for an English pamphlet. He was really kind.

I went there at 3pm on Sunday and there was practically no one. It was nice and quiet.

I found the shape of the kofun peculiar. I never saw something like that. Really interesting.

The view is spectacular. You can see the famous Akashi Bridge.

I went with the bicycle. You can leave it next to the entrance.

４５年ぶりに五色塚古墳にきました。
I came to this place for the first time in 45 years. When I was in high school, I came here on my way home from school and was hit by the sea breeze.
The Goshikizuka Tumulus is a huge anterior-posterior tumulus built at the southern end of the Tarumi hill in the western part of Kobe City, in the southern part of Hyogo Prefecture, with the Akashi Strait below and Awaji Island on the opposite bank.

The Goshikizuka Kofun, “five colored tomb”, is the largest keyhole burial tomb in Hyogo Prefecture.

all those steps lead to the terrace.. where you can look at the amazing view of the Akashi Kaikyo Bridge !!

There is a free parking lot near the Tumulus. The entrance is free, they just need to measure your temperature and then you can visit this place freely.
Free to enter, quite impressive aerial view. Clean & neat. No shade on hot day

A bit of walk from the station, but the view at the top is superb. The tomb itself is a interesting piece about Japanese history. The staffs kindly explained about the tomb, the nearby bridge and some places to go in the surrounding area to us

data.formatted_address: 68 Honmachi, Himeji, Hyogo 670-0012, Japan
data.name: Himeji Castle

reviews.text: The castle is a stunning example of Japanese architecture, often referred to as the “White Heron Castle” due to its elegant, white appearance. The interiors are well-preserved, offering a fascinating glimpse into feudal Japan. Climbing to the top provides breathtaking views of the city and surrounding area. The grounds are beautifully maintained, with lovely gardens and pathways.

Such a stunning castle! We were lucky to arrive when it opened and there was a local guide/docent who took us around and explained the history and architecture. (Thank you Yoko Nakamura!) She walked us through all 7 levels and told us secrets and stories we would not have known otherwise. The garden was also beautiful. This is the best castle I have seen in Japan thus far.

Absolutely loved it! Gorgeous from the outside and in. Yes you have to take off your shoes but the bags are reused so not a total waste, the crowd was big for us so moving around was easy enough and it was ¥1050 including access to the gardens! The smaller keeps and corridors were far less busy than the main keep and the information available in them via boards and interactive displays was excellent. A stunning castle and well deserved of a visit and your time!

Amazing historic castle. Combo ticket with garden is ¥1050 and well worth the cost. Lots of stairs to get through all 6 floors of the castle. Photos are allowed inside, but you are there to see architecture, as the rooms are mostly empty.

Amazing historic castle! Well worth a stop if you are traveling by. So easy to just jump.of the train, store your luggage in a locker at the station and do the quick walk to the palace. It is a huge are with a lot to see. So many cool details ans history! Loved to climb the castle and get a view of the city!

data.formatted_address: ゴールドウッズ三宮ビル ３階, 1-chōme-1-9 Nakayamatedōri, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0004, Japan
data.name: THE CASTLE

reviews.text:
A great place for atmosphere and the fuse was unbelievably flavorful and savory.  I wish the portions were bigger. They leave you wanting more.
The cocktails were well done with a perfect Negroni.  The host, Den , provided great conversation and recommendations. The carnitas tacos were delicious.

While in Osaka a few months back, my friends and I decided to take a chance on this restaurant and bar in Sannomiya. It was so close to the station and the reviews were great. When we went inside the lights were dimmed so the atmosphere was very different than we saw in the photos on Google, but the music and the vibe were so fun.

We got started with some drinks. Unfortunately, their Cannabis Beast cocktail was sold out, but we ordered several other drinks from the menu. There was a delicious cocktail called the Domme. I highly recommend ordering that one. The servers, bartenders, and chefs were so friendly, nice, and very informative on how the drinks and food were made. We had such a great time and I'll definitely be back when I'm back in Sannomiya in the future. Thanks for treating us so well!

The Castle is a very elegant and classy hidden bar with a speak easy feel to it.

I was served by Conner and he was an absolute pleasure to talk to. Conner being a native Kobe resident who has worked in several bars in Sannomia area over the past 15 years has a lot of recommendations on places to go to especially when it comes to authentic Kobe dining experience.

I find Conner to be extremely passionate when it comes to preparing and serving cocktails and he takes the time to explain what he’s making. I ordered a Moscow Mule and he prepared an amazing one using Wasabi infused vodka and dried ginger - served in a classic copper mug. It was truly was delicious.

The Castle is recommended if you want to meet people or if you want to host a party or a large gathering as the space is set up extremely well for this. It’s also very easy to find as it’s less then 100 meters from the JR Sannomia Train Station.

Highly recommended if you are visiting Sannomia, Kobe.

This place is beyond fantastic for a drink, some food and an amazing vibe. I cannot even express how lovely the staff are and how great their drink selection and alcohol quality is!
True masters of their craft, do yourself a favour and try this place out for an unforgettable night!

Best Negroni I've had in Japan over the last few years. The heavenly taste was proof enough of the extreme care and passion that had gone into making it. We also had a mocktail called "She So Cute", which quite wittily was a play on the Japanese Shiso, and that was mad delicious as well.
Alongside the drinks, we ordered their tacos, which were small in size, but what they lacked in size, they more than made up for in taste and quality.
To add more, they also serve a pretty cool Shisha (hookah) which unlike the traditional design, is served in a box-like container filled with ice. It was nicotine-free so that's a plus for people who don't want nicotine in their Shisha. Very light and vape-like.
Give them a visit if you were in Sannomiya and craving some nice food/drinks/shisha.

data.name: Hyogo Castle Ruin

reviews.author_name: 小林素明[大阪]パーソナルトレーナー
reviews.text:
About 15 minutes walk from JR Hyogo Station. There are no remains, only stone monuments. Due to the excavation of the Shinkawa Canal in the 7th year of Meiji, the center of the castle ruins seems to have become a riverbed. [Hyogo Castle was built by the Ikeda clan. ]

You can learn more about the Hyogo Castle ruins and the Hyogo Prefectural Office at the Hyogo Prefectural Hyogotsu Museum, which is a 5-minute walk from here.

No historical remains of the castle remain.
It is said to have been built in the 16th century. During the Edo period, it was a secondment destination for the Osaka Magistrate's Office, and during the Meiji period, Hirobumi Ito and others were appointed as the prefectural office.
There is a museum of the first Hyogo Prefectural Office that opened two years ago next to Aeon across the river, so you can listen to the details there.

Currently, the remains cannot be seen, but when Aeon Mall was being rebuilt, the stone walls and other areas were investigated.
Materials can be viewed at the Hyogotsu Museum.

I think it would be a good idea to enjoy it by imagining a castle buried under Aeon Mall.

The castle was built by Tsuneoki Ikeda, who was awarded the land of Hyogo as a reward for his success in the battle against Murashige Araki.
The castle ruins have been turned into residential lots and there are no remains.

It began when Tsuneoki Ikeda built a castle in the Tensho era near Hyogo Port, which flourished as Owada Tomari since ancient times. It is said that the surrounding area later became Taikōkura, and Katsumoto Katagiri entered the castle as a magistrate, and the name was changed from Hyogo Castle to Katagiri Jinya. It is said that Korean envoys frequently used it when they visited Korea.
In early modern times, a jinya was set up as the Hyogotsu magistrate of the Amagasaki domain, and in the 18th century, the Hyogotsu area was placed in the possession of the shogunate (tenryo) by the Jochi Rei, and was converted into a duty station. During the Meiji period, it became the first Hyogo Prefectural Office, but the Hyogo Castle ruins were destroyed early on when Hyogo Port was extensively renovated and the Hyogo Shinkawa Canal was created. In recent years, excavation surveys have been carried out from time to time, and it has been discovered that there is a budade and a moat, and it has also been pointed out that there may have been a castle tower.

reviews.text: Hanakuma Castle became known in history because of the series of battles fought by Murashige Araki, who defected from Oda Nobunaga. In 1578, Murashige Araki, the lord of Arioka Castle (Itami City), rebelled against Oda Nobunaga through ties with the Mori clan. Afterwards, Arioka Castle fell, and although they continued their resistance from Hanakuma Castle after passing through Amagasaki, the castle fell to Tsuneoki Ikeda of the Oda side in 1580. Although it is a mock-up, the castle is equipped with stone walls known as anato-zumi, which was a state-of-the-art technology from the Sengoku to Azuchi-Momoyama periods, and shows us that Kobe was an advanced region even back then. The JR Kobe Line runs through the south side of the castle ruins, and the coastline is also nearby, indicating that this was an important transportation hub back then. It seems that you can see the forward-thinking personality of Murashige Araki, who built a castle on this land.

2022/12/3. Castle ruins exploration “Hanakuma Castle Ruins”
I went to the ruins of Hanakuma Castle in Hanakuma-cho, Chuo-ku, Kobe City.
When heading to Kakogawa on the JR Kobe Line, I was always curious about the stone wall-like area that can always be seen on the mountainside as you drive a little west from Motomachi Station.
When I looked it up on Google, I found that it is now a park called Hanakuma Park, and there is a Hanakuma parking lot underground.
You can arrive at the site in about 5 minutes on foot from Hankyu Hanakuma Station.
All of the stone walls were modern (which is natural since there is an underground parking lot, but...), and there were no remnants of those days.
However, since the park is located on a fairly steep slope, the view from the top of the stone wall was very nice.
If this kind of view had been visible back then, I think it would have been a strategically important castle, as it could monitor not only the road but also movements on the sea.
It's about a 15 minute walk from Sannomiya, so I think it's worth visiting as part of your tour of the castle ruins, but there isn't much to see.
Rather than being a castle ruin, this place had a strong meaning as a local disaster prevention base.

While passing through Sannomiya, I noticed the castle Hanakuma Castle (^^). After doing a little research, I found the name of Murashige Araki, who betrayed Tsuneoki Ikeda and Nobunaga Oda, so I decided to check it out☺️. I entered the castle from the stone monument in Hanakuma Park, but the stone wall is somehow new 😳. It looks like it has been rebuilt and rebuilt after the earthquake. If you keep going up, there will be an explanatory text and you will see the castle tower and stone monuments~(^^). I was surprised to find Togoi.

The mountain side of Hanakuma Station on the Hankyu Kobe Line.
It's a fine stone wall, and if you climb it, it's quite high.
It seems that in the past, the sea was right in front of it. This castle was built by Oda Nobunaga and often appears in novels from that time🏯
I didn't know that the first battleship Yamato was built in Kobe and that Heihachiro Togo was the first captain.

I went for a walk on an autumn evening.
A park with stone walls that looks like the ruins of a castle, nestled in the cityscape at night.
It is a quiet park where you can see the night view of Meriken Park over the street where trains come and go.
It's small, but I like it.
There is a parking lot underground, and the manager was kind and courteous.

reviews.text: I've been to Japan twice now and Himeji Castle is a must go to place, especially during cherry blossom season.  Be warned though that some of the stairways in the castle are pretty steep and you may need to do a bit of ducking around beams, but still with the trip and time to explore.

Of all the castles it's not hard to understand why this is at the top of the list to visit. Beautifully maintained and renovated (not reconstructed like many, most) and quite inexpensive admission fee (and I highly recommend getting a combined admission to the lovely gardens nearby). The path and tour materials and information inside are great. Just be aware that there are a fair bit of stairs (quite steep) to climb up to the top and admire the inside of the wooden castle and the views.

If you're going to visit be in good shape. There is a lot of steep stairs. You will be winded but it will be worth it when you see the views from inside the castle. It felt like you traveled back in time.

We visited in the late afternoon on a cold, wet day in early March. Consequently, there were very few other visitors. I am sure it is very different in Golden Week or other peak times. The castle itself is a stunning wooden structure that has somehow survived through conflict and turmoil. Unlike many others, it is not a replica. Highly recommended.

Climbing up the iconic Himeji Castle Tower was an awe-inspiring experience! The tower's majestic architecture and rich historical significance make it an absolute must-visit. The panoramic views from the top are breathtaking, offering a glimpse into Japan's glorious past. A true gem that beautifully encapsulates Japan's cultural heritage!

Kon-yagura is twice the area of ​​Tatsumi-yagura, and seems to have played a role similar to that of a castle tower at Akashi Castle, which did not have a castle tower.
It can be seen from the platform of JR Akashi Station, and the sight of Kon Yagura and Tatsumi Yagura standing side by side gives the impression of being a symbol of Akashi Castle.

Visited on Sunday, November 26, 2023. I came on the last day of the autumn special viewing. I was able to listen to an explanation of Akashi Castle inside Kon Yagura, and get a panoramic view of Tatsumi Yagura, Akashi Akashi Observation Deck, and Akashi Ohashi Bridge.

☆Nationally designated important cultural property
Domestic castle, one of the 12 existing three-tiered turrets, Akashi Castle Honmaru southwest corner turret, north-south (flat side) 10.9m, east-west (gable side) 9.1m, height 13.6m, one from "Tatsumi yagura" in the southeast corner Large circumference🏯

☆When you look up from the front of the Sannomaru, the gable side faces the front, and the large part of the plane faces west, which is typical of a castle used to monitor the western regions, giving it a grand appearance.Bitchu Matsuyama Castle: approx. 11m, and Maruoka Castle: approx. 12.5m, of the 12 existing castle towers in Japan. If it were a tall, large, small-scale castle, it would definitely be the size of a castle tower.The castle tower was not built and the castle tower of Akashi Castle was replaced by ``Kon Yagura'', which is said to have been relocated from the abandoned Fushimi Castle under the orders of Hidetada Tokugawa. During the renovation work, it was discovered that there were traces of the castle being repurposed from another castle🤔
The exterior design is rich, with the first floor having a chidori gable to the north and south and a Kara gable to the west, the second floor having a Kara gable to the south and east, and a Chidori gable to the west, especially the double layered structure with a Chidori gable over the Kara gable on the east side of the second floor. Gables are very popular, and although they are small, the turrets have a rich variety of designs, and they are wonderful 👀

Visited on July 10, 2022.

It is said to have been relocated from Fushimi Castle and is the largest three-story turret within the castle. At Akashi Castle, where a castle tower was not built, it was used as a castle tower substitute. The size of the turret is 6 ken (10.94 m) in rows, 5 ken (9.15 m) in beam space, 7 ken (2 shaku 9 sun) in height (13.28 m), and weighs 340 tons, and the height of each floor is just over 3 m. Only the first floor is normally open to the public, and it has a simple appearance and a small internal area. There are no stairs inside the turret to go up to the second floor. It is the smallest of the three small castle towers, with a height of about 13 meters from the top of the stone wall. , The exterior has a simple appearance with little design, and the structure looks like a third turret part is placed on top of a two-tiered turret turret.The basement is a salt cellar, and during major repairs in the Showa era, there was a wooden sign that said ``salt cellar.'' Looks like it was found 😲

Himeji Castle Special Opening

*East small castle tower
It is located in the northeast part of the large castle tower Kuruwa. The east small castle tower was originally called Ushitora Sumiyagura. Appearance Mie. 3 floors above ground, 1 floor underground.
There is a houndstooth gable on the north side of the top floor to ensure a good view, and compared to other small castle towers, it is characterized by having no firelight windows or Chinese gables, and less decoration.

・Don't miss it...
A plover gable decorates the small castle tower. On the top floor, you can see the inside of this Houndstooth Gable during this special Himeji Castle exhibition.

*Himeji Castle, Himeji domain history.
・During the Ikeda period, Terumasa Ikeda of Mikawa Province (present-day Aichi Prefecture) and Yoshida Domain (present-day Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture), who had 150,000 koku, entered Himeji with 520,000 koku in Harima Province due to his military exploits at the Battle of Sekigahara. .
How did Lord Terumasa suddenly become the lord of such a large domain? It is true that he was credited with the battle of Sekigahara, but the main reason was that he had a connection with Tokuhime (widow of Ujinao Hojo), the beloved daughter of Tokugawa Ieyasu, who became his second wife. Lord Terumasa gave the Himeji domain to his eldest son Toshitaka, 280,000 koku of Okayama domain in Bizen (present-day Okayama prefecture) to his second wife Tokitaka and his own son Tadatsugu, and 60,000 koku of Awaji province to his third son Tadao, and to Terumasa's younger brother Nagayoshi. The Ikeda family had ties to the Tokugawa family, with the Tottori domain in Inaba (present-day Tottori Prefecture) as its territory, and the family owned more than 1 million koku of territory throughout the Kinai region. Furthermore, as befits the Ikeda family of the Himeji domain, which is a prestigious domain, it was Himeji that had the equivalent of 104,000 koku, which is 20% of the 520,000 koku table, and achieved a fiercely harsh government, raising the total power of the country and building a castle. It will be.

Under the One Country, One Castle Order, it was not treated as a castle, but as a castle or a dome, and the territory included Miki Castle with 37,000 koku of land, Toshimasa Ikeda with Akashi Castle (fleet castle) with 5,000 koku, and Takasago Castle with Nakamura Shudonosuke. Masakatsu placed 10,000 koku for Narifusa Arao at Tatsuno Castle (Kikagoyama Castle), 32,000 koku for Yoshiyuki Ikeda at Hirafuku Castle (Rigami Castle), and 32,000 koku for Nagamasa Ikeda at Ako Castle (Kariya Castle).

When Ikeda Terumasa died in 1613, his second son Tadao was given the equivalent of 130,000 koku of land in western Harima, making the Okayama domain worth 390,000 koku.
(The branch family already had 20,000 koku.) In 1617, when Toshitaka Ikeda, the second lord of the domain, died at the young age of 33, Toshitaka's eldest son Mitsumasa became the lord of the domain at the age of 3, but he was not a young prince. Because Himeji, which was a strategic location, could not be left in charge, he was transferred to Inaba Tottori for 320,000 koku.

* Terumasa Ikeda
He was born in Seishu, Owari Province (present-day Aichi Prefecture) as the second son of Tsuneoki Ikeda, a senior vassal of Lord Nobunaga Oda. He became a Genpuku and took the name Terumasa. In 1573, he was adopted by Yoshihisa Arao, his maternal uncle, and became the lord of Kida Castle. His first battle was at the Battle of Arioka Castle, where Araki Murashige and his son rebelled against Lord Oda Nobunaga. In 1580, at the Battle of Hanakuma Castle, he took up his position on Kita-Suwagamine and defeated five or six people, achieving great fame. In 1582, he went to battle against Koshu. After Lord Nobunaga was defeated by Mitsuhide Akechi in the Honnoji Incident, Hideyoshi Hashiba arrived at Amagasaki after attacking the Chugoku region, and joined Terumasa's father, Tsuneoki Ikeda. It was promised that Hideyoshi's nephew Hidetsugu would be Tsuneoki's son-in-law, and that Terumasa would be adopted by Lord Hideyoshi, and Tsuneoki became the lord of Ogaki Castle in Mino Province (present-day Gifu Prefecture), but the relationship between Lord Hideyoshi and Lord Ieyasu After his father and older brother were killed in the battle of Komaki and Nagakute, he inherited Mino Ogaki with 130,000 koku. Afterwards, he became the lord of Gifu Castle. He served in the conquest of Kishu, the campaign of Toyama (Sassa Narimasa conquest), and the pacification of Kyushu, and in 1587, in recognition of his military merits and achievements, he was given the surname Hashiba and Toyotomi.
In 1590, he participated in the Odawara conquest and Oshu attack. As a result of his military exploits, Mikawa Yoshida was awarded 152,000 koku. Around the same time, Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI also entered Owari, and it is said that Terumasa himself entered the neighboring country with Hidetsugu.

He did not participate in the Bunroku War (dispatch of troops to Korea), but became Hidetsugu's close apprentice in Japan and assumed the post of Togoku Keigo.
He indirectly participated in the Bunroku War, and was involved in supplying food and rice to Nagoya Castle, the front-line base for the Bunroku War, and building large warships. He was also involved in the construction of Fushimi Castle and Tanai Castle, and through the mediation of Lord Hideyoshi, he adopted Tokugawa Ieyasu's beloved daughter Tokuhime as his second wife. Although he already had a legal wife, Itohime (of the Nakagawa family), the relationship between Itohime and the Tokuhime was good. After this, through the mediation of Hidenari Nakagawa, he swore loyalty to Lord Tokugawa Ieyasu before the Battle of Sekigahara.

In 1595, when Kanpaku Toyotomi Hidetsugu fell from power, many of his wives and concubines were killed, but Terumasa's younger sister, Wakamandokoro, was spared as an exception and treated with special care. be treated. During the Toyotomi era, Lord Terumasa was treated like a member of the Toyotomi clan.

After the death of Toyotomi Hideyoshi in 1598, the civilian faction led by Ishida Mitsunari and the militant faction led by Masanori Fukushima and Kiyomasa Kato clashed. Lord Terumasa, together with the militant faction, commits the Ishida Mitsunari attack.
In the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, although he did not go directly to Sekigahara, he participated in the attack by Hidenobu Oda (grandson of Nobunaga) on the side of the western army defending Gifu Castle, and occupied Mino (Gifu) country. Furthermore, it will facilitate control and guarantee the protection and safety of the people within Mino.
In the main battle, he will be responsible for holding back the forces of Hidemoto Mori and Hiroie Yoshikawa. After the war, Lord Hidetada Tokugawa conquered and occupied Mino Province under Lord Terumasa, protected his territory, and furthermore, for his achievements in protecting the people of Mino, he became the Nawabushi of Harima Himeji with 520,000 koku and joined the ranks of Kunimochi daimyo. Chiyukitaka became the 8th highest rank among feudal lords in Japan, and was the first person outside of the Tokugawa clan to become a major general of the Ukonoe (Junior Fourth Rank).

From 1601 to 1609, Himeji Castle and the castle town underwent large-scale renovations, and at the same time, river improvement and development projects were carried out in the Kako River basin, upstream areas of the Kako River, and Takagawa River, as well as river improvements in the downstream area. We carry out development projects and carry out urban development projects in the Takasago area. He also worked with various feudal lords on the construction of Edo Castle and Nagoya Castle, and at Sasayama Castle, he became the general construction magistrate together with Takatora Todo, a master castle builder. Even when Ise Jingu was destroyed by fire, the Maniden was rebuilt.
In 1611, he attended a meeting between Prince Ieyasu and Toyotomi Hideyori at Nijo Castle in Kyoto. In 1987, he became the first person other than a daimyo from the Tokugawa clan to become a junior third rank councilor. At the same time, he was allowed to use the surname Matsudaira. Prime Minister Matsudaira Harima and the people began to talk about this. The family owned more than 1 million koku and had a lot of status, making the foundation of the Ikeda family's prosperity solid until the Meiji period.
In January of the same year, he contracted paralysis and was hospitalized. The second Tokugawa shogun, Hidetada, sent four letters of sympathy to Terumasa's eldest son, Toshitaka. In August of the same year, he recovered and was promoted to Junior Third Rank Councillor, and expressed his gratitude to Lord Hidetada at Edo Castle for the surname Matsudaira.
After that, he returned to Himeji, but became paralyzed again and died at the age of 50. Upon hearing of Terumasa's death, Toyotomi Hideyori and senior retainers of the Toyotomi family were shocked and mourned his death.

In the Meiji period, he was given the second rank of second rank.

*At the Nishinomaru ruins, we will introduce the history of the Honda family, the next lords of the domain after the Ikeda family. Also, let's talk about the strongest unrivaled man during the Sengoku period.
*At the Watari Yagura, we introduce the history of Himeji from the Sengoku period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period before the Ikeda family.
