This is a famous castle that was the setting for Hideyoshi Hashiba's Battle of Miki.

It's right away from Mikigami-no-maru station. There is a tourist information sign near the station. There are steep stairs up to the main enclosure. It was an unexpected turn of events, and it turned out to be a good leg workout.

There are almost no remains of the castle tower, but the view from the ruins of the castle tower is wonderful. The castle tower has a nice view.

This castle ruins was the site of a battle between Hashiba Hideyoshi (Oda clan) and Bessho clan that took place from 1578 to 1580. We could also see the remains of the main camp of Mt. Hirai where Hideyoshi Hashiba took up his position when he faced Miki Castle.

The scenery was good, with a wide view of the Mikasa River and the Miki city area, and the view of the Kobe Electric Railway crossing the iron bridge was quite impressive.

data.formatted_address: 2603 Battlefield Pkwy, Fort Oglethorpe, GA 30742, USA
data.name: Kobe Hibachi & Sushi

reviews.text: Been going to Kobe with the family for a longgg time. Their food has always been good but more recently it's been getting more greasy. It's hibachi food, what does one expect? I know, but it used to be not as greasy if that makes any sense. The food that night was absolutely amazing. There weren't a lot of people which was very weird. It was a Friday night at dinner time. That place used to be PACKED. Anyhow, the food was amazing, the waiter was okay, and the chef did good.

We really love to celebrate just everyday life by coming here on occasion. We don't really know what makes this food taste so amazing, but it is unbelievable! The white sauce and teriyaki sauce are only icing on the cake, so to speak!    And now, about the entertainment...the excitement of watching your food being cooked before your eyes in such a dramatic and FIREY manner is just FUN!! MY personal favorite is the onion volcano!
It is a bit more than we usually spend on a night out, but the amount of food you get, you can usually have a whole meal left over for another meal the next day! I highly recommend trying this place out of you are looking for something different and fun...I will say, if you are wanting to have a quiet place to have good dinner conversation, this really isn't the place for that.
Excellent food & service. Price has gone up a good bit, but still love to go. Park around door & sides or to tight & small if you drive a crew cab long bed HD truck.

If I could rate yall zero stars, I definitely WOULD.
The service was the absolute worst experience I’ve ever had. We arrived in ample time before they were about to close. They were about to seat us in a booth, the floors were greasy and wet..
The cook, SNEEZED in his forearm and wiped his nose on his arm. I was disgusted. 😩 The waiter brought our check before the cook was even done making our food. Proceeded to walk away and stared us down from across the room. Came RIGHT BACK to see if the check was ready, again - the cook was STILL preparing our food. So he took literally ONE step back and waited for payment. I felt so disrespected and annoyed at this point.
We paid for the meal and told the cook thank you. I will NEVER, EVERRRRR EAT HERE AGAIN. The disrespect was LOUD!

Very friendly staff that made our visit an outstanding experience. There is an attractive aquarium with a variety of fish swimming near at the Host greeting area. Special thanks to my daughter for requesting to have supper there. There were 5 of us that enjoyed 4 entrees, 2 different appetizers, and a couple of desserts for right at $100. Very much worth every cent! We will definitely visit again.

reviews.text: This is a nice station located at the northern end of Kobe, with a calm atmosphere, with the city and river on the south side, and a relaxing mountain with lush trees on the north side. We can also see private houses between the mountains. …

The real life Shin Kobe station as seen in Suzume no Tojimari. Was here last summer (2023) and fall of 2019. Both times we were here, we visited the adjacent Nunobiki Herb Garden and rode the ropeway. There are Kobe beef bentos for sale here (although I'd splurge and go to Sannomiya about 10 mins ride from here for the real deal). Plenty of locker spaces. And yes the shinkansen stops here.

A really special Shinkansen centric station. Due to space limit, there is only one platform each way. This makes transferring between trains of the same direction super easy, just get off, wait and enter. Especially for travelers who use JR Pass and travels between Kyushu/Chugoku and Kyoto/Nagoya/Tokyo regions. Plus you also get to see a lot of Shinkansen trains because of the frequency. Seems like the ekibens are not really special. And the station itself is quite old. Also seems like it is kinda hard to access Kobe and you might be better off transferring to Limited express trains in Osaka instead.

shinkansen train station.  I can't find the train lines that connect to the station.  Quite a difficult journey.  and all the stations have almost no internet, which is extremely inconvenient for a tourist like me, who can't find trains and routes!
Internet is quite a luxury at JR stations!

Shin means new.
If you want to take shinkansen to Tokyo or another prefecture in Japan, you can go to shin-Kobe station.

You can directly go to the shinkansen line or have the reservation seat first at the JR office on the station.
If you do not have the reservation, you have to notice which car (Gerbong kereta) that provide the unreservation passanger. You need to see the running text LED display the information of that.

If you lost the train, you can wait for the next train... so dont worry. The think that we need to do as the new comer in Japan is stay awake.. wkwkw and read every sign, then you will get familiar with it. Or you can ask the officer. They will help you, some of them can understand english, though sometimes they could not reply you in english.

Perched high atop Mount Maya, Kikuseidai offers visitors a breathtaking vantage point from which to admire the twinkling lights of Kobe and the surrounding region, as well as to marvel at the beauty of the night sky. As its name suggests, Kikuseidai, or "Star Viewing Platform," is the perfect spot for stargazing and taking in the majesty of the cosmos.

Accessing Kikuseidai typically involves a journey by cable car or hiking trail, both of which offer their own unique perspectives on the surrounding landscape. Whether ascending through lush forests on foot or gliding smoothly through the air in a cable car, the journey to Kikuseidai is an adventure in itself, promising stunning views and memorable experiences along the way.

Upon reaching the platform, we are greeted by panoramic vistas that stretch as far as the eye can see, with the lights of Kobe twinkling below like a sea of stars. The city's bustling streets and illuminated landmarks create a mesmerizing tableau against the backdrop of the darkened sky, while the tranquil beauty of the surrounding mountains adds a sense of serenity and grandeur to the scene.

As night falls and the sky darkens, Kikuseidai truly comes alive, offering an unrivaled opportunity to observe the wonders of the night sky. Away from the glare of city lights, the stars shine brightly overhead, their brilliance illuminating the darkness and inspiring awe and wonder in all who behold them. Visitors can spend hours gazing up at the heavens, picking out constellations, and marveling at the beauty and vastness of the cosmos.

In addition to stargazing, Kikuseidai also offers opportunities for relaxation and reflection, with benches and seating areas where visitors can sit back, unwind, and soak in the tranquil ambiance of the mountain surroundings. Whether alone, with loved ones, or in the company of fellow stargazers, Kikuseidai provides a peaceful retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life, allowing visitors to reconnect with nature and find moments of serenity and inspiration.

Fantastic, amazing view of one of the world's great metro areas.  Just that alone is worth coming up for.  Nice cable car and funicular railway.  Kids really enjoyed that.

Cute little cafe indoors, books, decent snacks, ice cream. All food quite reasonably priced.  An old Zen monastery right above with trails.  There is a lot to do and see up here.

I can't help but compare,

A while ago, when my child went to try it out and was watching from below with his hands, the instructor of how to lose weight with buck teeth, a man wearing glasses, came to the slider and asked me why I thought it wouldn't slide. When I told him that I didn't understand, he told me that it was because I had a different side of him and asked me to take a closer look, which made me very uncomfortable. Others were great.
For 1,500 yen per person, you can enjoy a fairly authentic athletic experience. There were several zip lines that I enjoyed.

This is an athletic facility located in Shiawase no Mura in Kita Ward, Kobe City. We will do it with a helmet and harness, but children who are afraid of heights may get stuck. In that case, the staff will help you, so it's okay.
Anyone who is 5 years old and over 110cm tall can participate, so the athletics itself is not that difficult and does not require physical strength.
I don't think it will be that tiring as it will take you less than an hour to go to the rooftop and tree top if it's not busy. The long slide at the end of Tree Top was so much fun that I wanted to try it again.
The experience fee for the two types is 1,500 yen, and it's not an all-you-can-play experience, but a single lap fee for adults and children. There is a discount system from the second week, but if it was a little cheaper, I would give it 4 stars. I think both adults and children can easily enjoy it. I recommend it.

reviews.text:
2023/6/24 Saturday visit
I experienced the canyon drop. A simple attraction where you step inside a sphere and just roll down a slope. But it's quite excellent. I couldn't help but experience it twice because it felt like something I had never experienced before.
During this hot season, you fill the sphere with water, so your whole body gets soaked. It's more like a plastic greenhouse than a place to enjoy a splash, so it's probably filled with water to relieve the heat.

【important point】
・As mentioned above, it will be messy, so you will need a swimsuit or a change of clothes.
・For parking lot P2, go straight on the right after entering the gate, go up the hill and go straight ahead, then enter the parking lot you will see. However, it is not right away from this parking lot, and it takes about 10 minutes to walk to the platform.
・There is a slope all the way to the platform, and there is no shade at all. You will have to wait for over an hour, so you will need a parasol to protect yourself from heat stroke.
・You will need a yellow wristband and a weight check before the experience. You can receive yellow wristbands by filling out a disclaimer agreement, but you will need one for each person, so be sure to prepare one in advance or get one at the waiting area below.
・I don't know the details, but for some reason only one of the three lanes is often in operation, and although there are no people, the waiting time is long.
・You can leave your luggage at the platform and take it to the lower drop-off area in a cart. However, they only carry luggage, so if someone says they don't want to ride, you'll have to go down the hill again.
・My daughter was afraid, but unlike Kenji Moriwaki at Aiseki Shokudo, her hands did not fall off or her hair became thinner.
Since it's the soaking wet version in the summer, it was relatively empty and the kids had a lot of fun trying it out over and over again.

It seems to be crowded and there is a long wait, so I can't go on a day trip.
There are no fastpasses, and numbered tickets run out in the morning.
Weekdays aside, you shouldn't come on Saturdays and Sundays.

It feels like this is a scam! ! !
We arrived here at 9:30 in the morning
Because there were a lot of people waiting in the trapeze team, the administrator here told us to go to P3 to play other events first and come back in the afternoon. As a result, when we arrived before one o'clock, we were told that the payment was over, which was really unacceptable.
When queuing, there is an employee holding a fast-pass ticket. You can go to the fast-pass line after paying 1,000 yuan. If you want to pay for going to the fast-pass, please explain it before queuing. There are no rules in selling tickets during the queuing process!
Moreover, even though the payment is over, there are still customers coming in from other places, so what is the meaning of this case? I really can't understand it.
The facilities here are simply out of proportion to the ticket price. It is not an exaggeration to say it is a scam! High price IQ tax! ! !
Qian who has never been here! Ten thousand! No! want! Come! ! !

Canyon Drop, I was told to wait 100 minutes, but even after waiting 180 minutes, I couldn't get on, so the ride was canceled at the end.
It was a shame that I had to return to Nesta Resort.
This will collapse and I want it to collapse. I'll never go again

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-3-18 Sakaemachidōri, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0023, Japan
data.name: Kobe Chinatown Nankin-machi

reviews.text: What an amazing atmosphere, the hustle and bustle of Chinatown in Kobe is a great place to start the evening! it was also magical with mist and a light rain... take cash with you! there is no card reading machines... however if you do need to withdraw money at an ATM there is a 7 11 nearby and they have an ATM.

Kobe's Chinatown offers a vibrant and captivating atmosphere that instantly draws you in. The bustling streets are alive with energy, as locals and tourists alike weave through the maze of stalls and shops. The vibrant colors, aromatic scents, and lively chatter create an atmosphere that is truly infectious.

One of the most striking aspects of Kobe's Chinatown is the abundance of stalls offering a variety of culinary delights. While wandering through the narrow alleyways, you'll find yourself surrounded by vendors tempting you with a plethora of tantalizing treats. From steaming baskets of dumplings to freshly baked buns, the options seem endless yet enticingly familiar.

The heart of Chinatown beats with the rhythm of dumplings sizzling on griddles and the soft hiss of steam escaping bamboo baskets. Each stall offers its own take on classic dishes, showcasing a rich tapestry of flavors and culinary traditions. Whether you're craving traditional pork dumplings or adventurous flavors like shrimp and chive, there's something to satisfy every palate.

Beyond the culinary delights, Kobe's Chinatown exudes a sense of history and culture that is palpable with every step. The architecture reflects a blend of Japanese and Chinese influences, with ornate gateways and intricate facades adorning the streets. Exploring the narrow lanes reveals hidden gems, from ancient temples to quaint teahouses, each offering a glimpse into the area's rich heritage.

Amidst the hustle and bustle, the sense of community in Kobe's Chinatown is unmistakable. Locals and visitors mingle freely, sharing stories and laughter over shared meals. It's a place where strangers become friends over a shared love of food and culture.

In conclusion, Kobe's Chinatown is a feast for the senses and a must-visit destination for anyone exploring the vibrant city. From the tantalizing aromas to the rich tapestry of flavors, it's an experience that will leave a lasting impression on your taste buds and your heart.

One of the only 3 Chinatowns in Japan, this one in Kobe is probably the smallest amongst them all. Its just a straight street with mostly food stalls and restaurants lined up on both sides for you to try the street food. Nothing funky, just simply Chinese cuisine mostly to serve your appetite. lol.

We decided to visit on Saturday afternoon so that it would be crowded and food would be freshly prepared. We got there around 4pm. and the crowd was less than expected.

We started off with Peking duck wrap and fatty pork belly bun. The wrap was quite solid and dry as it might be displayed for some time. The bun was just ok. Not wow at all.

We had tried a couple more places recommended by YouTubers but, well, we just didn’t think food there was that great compared to somewhere else.

It is not a must to visit when in Kobe if you have been to China Town anywhere else in the world.

I loved this Chinatown and would go back to it next time to eat.

(We were not able to eat this time as we had had a big lunch and were having Kobe steak for dinner.)

The Chinatown is big.
It is clean.
It is tourist friendly.
There are many food stalls - mostly offering the same items.
There are a few Spider-Mans along the walls so it could be fun trying to find them all in this area and the surroundings.

I would recommend this Chinatown for a walk through even if not stopping by to eat in it. There are many side alleys that looked interesting which we didn’t get to walk down.

“Great location, poor value ”
The hotel's location is fantastic, with easy access to shopping and other attractions. The cleanliness of the rooms was top-notch, and we had no issues with the hot water or Wi-Fi. However, the staff left much to be desired, with unhelpful attitudes and poor service. Despite the great facilities, we felt that the value for money was not up to par. reviews.text: Lightning along the street, bright and warm
Check this place out, great place and a chance to explore some history!

◼️Kobe Foreign Settlement Monument
A stone monument located in Chuo Ward, Kobe City. A stone monument next to the west sidewalk of the Kobe Daimaru department store building.

Built: April 1967

●A stone monument in the middle of the flower bed next to the sidewalk. It was built to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the opening of Kobe Port. The entire settlement was designed by British civil engineer J.W. Hart and is said to have existed until around 1899.

Now it is Nanjing Street across the road from the west side. In Nanjing Street, people from Shanghai and Hong Kong who were not allowed to live in the settlements inevitably gathered in a nearby area where they could easily meet foreigners.

This monument was casually placed near the northwest corner of the Daimaru Kobe store. Having lived in Kobe for over 60 years, I only recently learned of its existence.
I believe that the townscape of this settlement is one of the symbols of how our ancestors used their wisdom to come to terms with the world in order to escape colonial rule as the imperialism of Western powers swept the world. I am.
I think this is a very meaningful monument as a connection point with Western culture, such as the Kobe Incident that occurred in front of Sannomiya Shrine, which is right next to here, and Nankinmachi, which was established when Chinese people who came to act as interpreters for Westerners settled there. Masu.
